play.title:
The Lamentable Tragedy of
Titus Andronicus.

scene.stagedir: Flouriſh. Enter the Tribunes and Senators aloſt And then enter Saturninus and his Followers at one doore, and Baſsianus and his Followers at the other, with Drum & Colours

speech.speaker: Saturninus.
speech.line: Noble Patricians, Patrons of my right,
Defend the iuſtice of my Cauſe with Armes.
And Countrey-men, my louing Followers,
Pleade my Succeſſiue Title with your Swords.
I was the ﬁrſt borne Sonne, that was the laſt
That wore the Imperiall Diadem of Rome:
Then let my Fathers Honours liue in me,
Nor wrong mine Age with this indignitie.

speech.speaker: Baſsianus.
speech.line: Romaines, Friends, Followers,
Fauourers of my Right:
If euer Baſsianus, Cæſars Sonne,
Were gracious in the eyes of Royall Rome,
Keepe then this paſſage to the Capitoll:
And ſuffer not Diſhonour to approach
Th’ Imperiall Seate to Vertue: conſecrate
To Iuſtice, Continence, and Nobility:
But let Deſert in pure Eleƈtion ſhine;
And Romanes, ﬁght for Freedome in your Choice.
speech.stagedir: Enter Marcus Andronicus aloſt with the Crowne.
speech.line: Princes, that ſtriue by Faƈtions, and by Friends,
Ambitiouſly for Rule and Empery:
Know, that the people of Rome for whom we ſtand
A ſpeciall Party, haue by Common voyce
In Eleƈion for the Romane Emperie,
Choſen Andronicus, Sur-named Pious,
For many good and great deſerts to Rome.
A Nobler man, a brauer Warriour,
Liues not this day within the City Walles.
He by the Senate is accited home
From weary Warres againſt the barbarous Gothes,
That with his Sonnes (a terror to our Fœs)
Hath yoak’d a Nation ſtrong, train’d vp in Armes.
Ten yeares are ſpent, ſince ﬁrſt he vndertooke
This Cauſe of Rome, and chaſticed with Armes
Our Enemies pride. Fiue times he hath return’d
Bleeding to Rome, bearing his Valiant Sonnes
In Cofﬁns from the Field.
And now at laſt, laden with Honours Spoyles,
Returnes the good Andronicus to Rome,
Renowned Titus, ﬂouriſhing in Armes.
Let vs intreat, by Honour of his Name,
Whom (worthily) you would haue now ſucceede,
And in the Capitoll and Senates right,
Whom you pretend to Honour and Adore,
That you withdraw you, and abate your Strength,
Diſmiſſe your Followers, and as Suters ſhould,
Pleade your Deſerts in Peace and Humbleneſſe.

speech.speaker: Saturnine.
speech.line: How fayre the Tribune ſpeakes,
To calme my thoughts.

speech.speaker: Baſsia.
speech.line: Marcus Andronicus, ſo I do afﬁe
In thy vprightneſſe and Integrity:
And ſo I Loue and Honor thee, and thine,
Thy Noble Brother Titus, and his Sonnes,
And Her (to whom my thoughts are humbled all)
Gracious Lauinia, Romes rich Ornament,
That I will heere diſmiſſe my louing Friends:
And to my Fortunes, and the Peoples Fauour,
Commit my Cauſe in ballance to be weigh’d.

scene.stagedir: Exit Souldiours.

speech.speaker: Saturnine.
speech.line: Friends, that haue beene
Thus forward in my Right,
I thanke you all, and heere Diſmiſſe you all,
And to the Loue and Fauour of my Countrey,
Commit my Selfe, my Perſon, and the Cauſe:
Rome, be as iuſt and gracious vnto me,
As I am conﬁdent and kinde to thee.
Open the Gates, and let me in.

speech.speaker: Baſsia.
speech.line: Tribunes, and me, a poore Competitor.

scene.stagedir: Flouriſh. They go vp into the Senat houſe.
Enter a Captaine.

speech.speaker: Cap.
speech.line: Romanes make way: the good Andronicus,
Patron of Vertue, Romes beſt Champion,
Succeſſefull in the Battailes that he ﬁghts,
With Honour and with Fortune is return’d,
From whence he circumſcribed with his Sword,
And brought to yoke the Enemies of Rome.

scene.stagedir: Sound Drummes and Trumpets. And then enter two of Titus Sonnes; After them, two men bearing a Cofﬁn couered with blacke, then two other Sonnes. Aﬅer them, Titus Andronicus, and then Tamora the Queene of Gothes, & her two Sonnes Chiron and Demetrius, with Aaron the Moore, and others, as many as can bee: They ſet downe the Cofﬁn, and Titus ſpeakes

speech.speaker: Andronicus.
speech.line: Haile Rome:
Viƈtorious in thy Mourning Weedes:
Lœ as the Barke that hath diſcharg’d his fraught,
Returnes with precious lading to the Bay,
From whence at ﬁrſt ſhe weigh’d her Anchorage:
Commeth Andronicus bound with Lawrell bowes,
To reſalute his Country with his teares,
Teares of true ioy for his returne to Rome,
Thou great defender of this Capitoll,
Stand gracious to the Rites that we intend.
Romaines, of ﬁue and twenty Valiant Sonnes,
Halfe of the number that King Priam had,
Behold the poore remaines aliue and dead!
Theſe that Suruiue, let Rome reward with Loue:
Theſe that I bring vnto their lateſt home,
With buriall amongſt their Aunceſtors.
Heere Gothes haue giuen me leaue to ſheath my Sword:
Titus vnkinde, and careleſſe of thine owne,
Why ſuffer’ſt thou thy Sonnes vnburied yet,
To houer on the dreadfull ſhore of Stix?
Make way to lay them by their Bretheren.
There greete in ſilence as the dead are wont,
And ſleepe in peace, ſlaine in your Countries warres:
O ſacred receptacle of my ioyes,
Sweet Cell of vertue and Nobilitie,
How many Sonnes of mine haſt thou in ſtore,
That thou wilt neuer render to me more?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Giue vs the proudeſt priſoner of the Gothes,
That we may hew his limbes, and on a pile
Ad manus fratrum, ſacriﬁce his ﬂeſh:
Before this earthly priſon of their bones,
That ſo the ſhadowes be not vnappeas’d,
Nor we diſturb’d with prodigies on earth.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: I giue him you, the Nobleſt that Suruiues,
The eldeſt Son of this diſtreſſed Queene.

speech.speaker: Tam.
speech.line: Stay Romaine Bretheren, gracious Conqueror,
Viƈtorious Titus, rue the teares I ſhed,
A Mothers teares in paſſion for her ſonne:
And if thy Sonnes were euer deere to thee,
Oh thinke my ſonnes to be as deere to mee.
Sufﬁceth not, that we are brought to Rome
To beautiﬁe thy Triumphs, and returne
Captiue to thee, and to thy Romaine yoake,
But muſt my Sonnes be ſlaughtred in the ſtreetes,
For Valiant doings in their Countries cauſe?
O! If to ﬁght for King and Common-weale,
Were piety in thine, it is in theſe:
Andronicus, ſtaine not thy Tombe with blood.
Wilt thou draw neere the nature of the Gods?
Draw neere them then in being mercifull.
Sweet mercy is Nobilities true badge,
Thrice Noble Titus, ſpare my ﬁrſt borne ſonne.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Patient your ſelfe Madam, and pardon me.
Theſe are the Brethren, whom you Gothes beheld
Aliue and dead, and for their Bretheren ſlaine,
Religiouſly they aske a ſacriﬁce:
To this your ſonne is markt, and die he muſt,
T’appeaſe their groaning ſhadowes that are gone.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Away with him, and make a ﬁre ſtraight,
And with our Swords vpon a pile of wood,
Let’s hew his limbes till they be cleane conſum’d.

scene.stagedir: Exit Sonnes with Alarbus.

speech.speaker: Tamo.
speech.line: O cruell irreligious piety.

speech.speaker: Chi.
speech.line: Was euer Scythia halfe ſo barbarous?

speech.speaker: Dem.
speech.line: Oppoſe me Scythia to ambitious Rome,
Alarbus gœs to reſt, and we ſuruiue,
To tremble vnder Titus threatning lookes.
Then Madam ſtand reſolu’d, but hope withall,
The ſelfe ſame Gods that arm’d the Queene of Troy
With opportunitie of ſharpe reuenge
Vpon the Thracian Tyrant in his Tent,
May fauour Tamora the Queene of Gothes,
(When Gothes were Gothes, and Tamora was Queene)
To quit the bloody wrongs vpon her fœs.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Sonnes of Andronicus againe.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: See Lord and Father, how we haue perform’d
Our Romaine rightes, Alarbus limbs are lopt,
And intrals feede the ſacriﬁſing ﬁre,
Whoſe ſmoke like incenſe doth perfume the skie.
Remaineth nought but to interre our Brethren,
And with low’d Larums welcome them to Rome.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Let it be ſo, and let Andronicus
Make this his lateſt farewell to their ſoules.
speech.stagedir: Flouriſh.Then Sound Trumpets, and lay the Cofﬁns in the Tombe.
speech.line: In peace and Honour reſt you heere my Sonnes,
Romes readieſt Champions, repoſe you heere in reſt,
Secure from worldly chaunces and miſtraps:
Heere lurks no Treaſon, heere no enuie ſwels,
Heere grow no damned grudges, heere are no ſtormes,
No noyſe, but ſilence and Eternall ſleepe,
In peace and Honour reſt you heere my Sonnes.

scene.stagedir: Enter Lauinia.

speech.speaker: Laui.
speech.line: In peace and Honour, liue Lord Titus long,
My Noble Lord and Father, liue in Fame:
Lœ at this Tombe my tributarie teares,
I render for my Bretherens Obſequies:
And at thy feete I kneele, with teares of ioy
Shed on the earth for thy returne to Rome.
O bleſſe me heere with thy viƈtorious hand,
Whoſe Fortune Romes beſt Citizens applau’d.

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: Kind Rome,
That haſt thus louingly reſeru’d
The Cordiall of mine age to glad my hart,
Lauinia liue, out-liue thy Fathers dayes:
And Fames eternall date for vertues praiſe.

speech.speaker: Marc.
speech.line: Long liue Lord Titus, my beloued brother,
Gracious Triumpher in the eyes of Rome.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Thankes Gentle Tribune,
Noble brother Marcus.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: And welcome Nephews from ſucceſfull wars,
You that ſuruiue and you that ſleepe in Fame:
Faire Lords your Fortunes are all alike in all,
That in your Countries ſeruice drew your Swords.
But ſafer Triumph is this Funerall Pompe,
That hath aſpir’d to Solons Happines,
And Triumphs ouer chaunce in honours bed.
Titus Andronicus, the people of Rome,
Whoſe friend in iuſtice thou haſt euer bene,
Send thee by me their Tribune and their truſt,
This Palliament of white and ſpotleſſe Hue,
And name thee in Eleƈtion for the Empire,
With theſe our late deceaſed Emperours Sonnes:
Be Candidatus then, and put it on,
And helpe to ſet a head on headleſſe Rome.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: A better head her Glorious body ﬁts,
Then his that ſhakes for age and feebleneſſe:
What ſhould I d’on this Robe and trouble you,
Be choſen with proclamations to day,
To morrow yeeld vp rule, reſigne my life,
And ſet abroad new buſineſſe for you all.
Rome I haue bene thy Souldier forty yeares,
And led my Countries ſtrength ſucceſſefully,
And buried one and twenty Valiant Sonnes,
Knighted in Field, ſlaine manfully in Armes,
In right and Seruice of their Noble Countrie:
Giue me a ſtaffe of Honour for mine age,
But not a Scepter to controule the world,
Vpright he held it Lords, that held it laſt.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Titus, thou ſhalt obtaine and aske the Emperie.

speech.speaker: Sat.
speech.line: Proud and ambitious Tribune can’ſt thou tell?

speech.speaker: Titus.
speech.line: Patience Prince Saturninus.

speech.speaker: Sat.
speech.line: Romaines do me right.
Patricians draw your Swords, and ſheath them not
Till Saturninus be Romes Emperour:
Andronicus would thou wert ſhipt to hell,
Rather then rob me of the peoples harts.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Proud Saturnine, interrupter of the good
That Noble minded Titus meanes to thee.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Content thee Prince, I will reſtore to thee
The peoples harts, and weane them from themſelues.

speech.speaker: Baſs.
speech.line: Andronicus, I do not ﬂatter thee
But Honour thee, and will dœ till I die:
My Faƈttion if thou ſtrengthen with thy Friend?
I will moſt thankefull be, and thankes to men
Of Noble mindes, is Honourable Meede.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: People of Rome, and Noble Tribunes heere,
I aske your voyces and your Suffrages,
Will you beſtow them friendly on Andronicus?

speech.speaker: Tribunes.
speech.line: To gratiﬁe the good Andronicus,
And Gratulate his ſafe returne to Rome,
The people will accept whom he admits.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Tribunes I thanke you, and this ſure I make,
That you Create your Emperours eldeſt ſonne,
Lord Saturnine, whoſe Vertues will I hope,
Reﬂeƈt on Rome as Tytans Rayes on earth,
And ripen Iuſtice in this Common-weale:
Then if you will eleƈt by my aduiſe,
Crowne him, and ſay: Long liue our Emperour.

speech.speaker: Mar. An.
speech.line: With Voyces and applauſe of euery ſort,
Patricians and Plebeans we Create
Lord Saturninus Romes Great Emperour.
And ſay, Long liue our Emperour Saturnine.

scene.stagedir: A long Flouriſh till they come downe.

speech.speaker: Satu.
speech.line: Titus Andronicus, for thy Fauours done,
To vs in our Eleƈtion this day,
I giue thee thankes in part of thy Deſerts,
And will with Deeds requite thy gentleneſſe:
And for an Onſet Titus to aduance
Thy Name, and Honorable Familie,
Lauinia will I make my Empreſſe,
Romes Royall Miſtris, Miſtris of my hart
And in the Sacred Pathan her eſpouſe:
Tell me Andronicus doth this motion pleaſe thee?

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: It doth my worthy Lord, and in this match,
I hold me Highly Honoured of your Grace,
And heere in ſight of Rome, to Saturnine,
King and Commander of our Common-weale,
The Wide-worlds Emperour, do I Conſecrate,
My Sword, my Chariot, and my Priſoners,
Preſents well Worthy Romes Imperiall Lord:
Receiue them then, the Tribute that I owe,
Mine Honours Enſignes humbled at my feete.

speech.speaker: Satu.
speech.line: Thankes Noble Titus, Father of my life,
How proud I am of thee, and of thy giﬅs
Rome ſhall record, and when I do forget
The leaſt of theſe vnſpeakable Deſerts,
Romans forget your Fealtie to me.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Now Madam are you priſoner to an Emperour,
To him that for your Honour and your State,
Will vſe you Nobly and your followers.

speech.speaker: Satu.
speech.line: A goodly Lady, truſt me of the Hue
That I would chooſe, were I to chooſe a new:
Cleere vp Faire Queene that cloudy countenance,
Though chance of warre
Hath wrought this change of cheere,
Thou com’ſt not to be made a ſcorne in Rome:
Princely ſhall be thy vſage euery way.
Reſt on my word, and let not diſcontent
Daunt all your hopes: Madam he comforts you,
Can make your Greater then the Queene of Gothes?
Lauinia you are not diſpleaſ’d with this?

speech.speaker: Lau.
speech.line: Not I my Lord, ſith true Nobilitie,
Warrants theſe words in Princely curteſie.

speech.speaker: Sat.
speech.line: Thankes ſweete Lauinia, Romans let vs gœ:
Ranſomleſſe heere we ſet our Priſoners free,
Proclaime our Honors Lords with Trumpe and Drum.

speech.speaker: Baſs.
speech.line: Lord Titus by your leaue, this Maid is mine.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: How ſir? Are you in earneſt then my Lord?

speech.speaker: Baſs.
speech.line: I Noble Titus, and reſolu’d withall,
To dœ my ſelfe this reaſon, and this right.

speech.speaker: Marc.
speech.line: Suum cuiquam, is our Romane Iuſtice,
This Prince in Iuſtice ceazeth but his owne.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: And that he will and ſhall, if Lucius liue.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Traytors auant, where is the Emperours Guarde?
Treaſon my Lord, Lauinia is ſurpriſ’d.

speech.speaker: Sat.
speech.line: Surpriſ’d, by whom?

speech.speaker: Baſs.
speech.line: By him that iuſtly may
Beare his Betroth’d, from all the world away.

speech.speaker: Muti.
speech.line: Brothers helpe to conuey her hence away,
And with my Sword Ile keepe this doore ſafe.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Follow my Lord, and Ile ſoone bring her backe.

speech.speaker: Mut.
speech.line: My Lord you paſſe not heere.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: What villaine Boy, bar’ſt me my way in Rome?

speech.speaker: Mut.
speech.line: Helpe Lucius helpe. He kils him.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: My Lord you are vniuſt, and more then ſo,
In wrongfull quarrell, you haue ſlaine your ſon.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Nor thou, nor he are any ſonnes of mine,
My ſonnes would neuer ſo diſhonour me.
Traytor reſtore Lauinia to the Emperour.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Dead if you will, but not to be his wife,
That is anothers lawfull promiſt Loue.

scene.stagedir: Enter aloſt the Emperour with Tamora and her two ſonnes, and Aaron the Moore

speech.speaker: Empe.
speech.line: No Titus, no, the Emperour needs her not,
Nor her, nor thee, nor any of thy ſtocke:
Ile truſt by Leiſure him that mocks me once.
Thee neuer: nor thy Trayterous haughty ſonnes,
Confederates all, thus to diſhonour me.
Was none in Rome to make a ſtale
But Saturnine? Full well Andronicus
Agree theſe Deeds, with that proud bragge of thine,
That ſaid’ſt, I beg’d the Empire at thy hands.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: O monſtrous, what reproachfull words are theſe?

speech.speaker: Sat.
speech.line: But gœ thy wayes, gœ giue that changing peece,
To him that ﬂouriſht for her with his Sword:
A Valliant ſonne in-law thou ſhalt enioy:
One, ﬁt to bandy with thy lawleſſe Sonnes,
To rufﬂe in the Common-wealth of Rome.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Theſe words are Razors to my wounded hart.

speech.speaker: Sat.
speech.line: And therefore louely Tamora Queene of Gothes,
That like the ſtately Thebe mong’ſt her Nimphs
Doſt ouer-ſhine the Gallant’ſt Dames of Rome,
If thou be pleaſ’d with this my ſodaine choyſe,
Behold I chooſe thee Tamora for my Bride,
And will Create thee Empreſſe of Rome.
Speake Queene of Goths doſt thou applau’d my choyſe?
And heere I ſweare by all the Romaine Gods,
Sith Prieſt and Holy-water are ſo neere,
And Tapers burne ſo bright, and euery thing
In readines for Hymeneus ſtand,
I will not reſalute the ſtreets of Rome,
Or clime my Pallace, till from forth this place,
I leade eſpouſ’d my Bride along with me.

speech.speaker: Tamo.
speech.line: And heere in ſight of heauen to Rome I ſweare,
If Saturnine aduance the Queen of Gothes,
Shee will a Hand-maid be to his deſires,
A louing Nurſe, a Mother to his youth.

speech.speaker: Satur.
speech.line: Aſcend Faire Queene,
Panthean Lords, accompany
Your Noble Emperour and his louely Bride,
Sent by the heauens for Prince Saturnine,
Whoſe wiſedome hath her Fortune Conquered,
There ſhall we Conſummate our Spouſall rites.

scene.stagedir: Exeunt omnes.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: I am not bid to waite vpon this Bride:
Titus when wer’t thou wont to walke alone,
Diſhonoured thus and Challenged of wrongs?

scene.stagedir: Enter Marcus and Titus Sonnes.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: O Titus ſee! O ſee what thou haſt done!
In a bad quarrell, ſlaine a Vertuous ſonne.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: No fooliſh Tribune, no: No ſonne of mine,
Nor thou, nor theſe Confedrates in the deed,
That hath diſhonoured all our Family,
Vnworthy brother, and vnworthy Sonnes.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: But let vs giue him buriall as becomes:
Giue Mutius buriall with our Bretheren.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Traytors away, he reſt’s not in this Tombe:
This Monument ﬁue hundreth yeares hath ſtood,
Which I haue Sumptuouſly re-ediﬁed.
Heere none but Souldiers, and Romes Seruitors,
Repoſe in Fame: None baſely ſlaine in braules,
Bury him where you can, he comes not heere.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: My Lord this is impiety in you,
My Nephew Mutius deeds do plead for him,
He muſt be buried with his bretheren.
And ſhall, or him we will accompany.

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: And ſhall! What villaine was it ſpake that word?
He that would vouch’d it in any place but heere.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: What would you bury him in my deſpight?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: No Noble Titus, but intreat of thee,
To pardon Mutius, and to bury him.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Marcus, Euen thou haſt ſtroke vpon my Creſt,
And with theſe Boyes mine Honour thou haſt wounded,
My fœs I dœ repute you euery one.
So trouble me no more, but get you gone.

speech.speaker: 1.Sonne.
speech.line: He is not himſelfe, let vs withdraw.

speech.speaker: 2.Sonne.
speech.line: Not I tell Mutius bones be buried.

scene.stagedir: The Brother and the ſonnes kneele.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Brother, for in that name doth nature plea’d.

speech.speaker: 2.Sonne.
speech.line: Father, and in that name doth nature ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Speake thou no more if all the reſt will ſpeede.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Renowned Titus more then halfe my ſoule.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Deare Father, ſoule and ſubſtance of vs all.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Suffer thy brother Marcus to interre
His Noble Nephew heere in vertues neſt,
That died in Honour and Lauinia's cauſe.
Thou art a Romaine, be not barbarous:
The Greekes vpon aduiſe did bury Aiax
That ſlew himſelfe: And Laertes ſonne,
Did graciouſly plead for his Funerals:
Let not young Mutius then that was thy ioy,
Be bar’d his entrance heere.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Riſe Marcus, riſe,
The diſmall’ſt day is this that ere I ſaw,
To be diſhonored by my Sonnes in Rome:
Well, bury him, and bury me the next.

scene.stagedir: They put him in the Tombe.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: There lie thy bones ſweet Mutius with thy friends.
Till we with Trophees do adorne thy Tombe.
No man ſhed teares for Noble Mutius,
He liues in Fame, that di’d in vertues cauſe.Exit.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: My Lord to ſtep out of theſe ſudden dumps,
How comes it that the ſubtile Queene of Gothes,
Is of a ſodaine thus aduanc’d in Rome?

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: I know not Marcus: but I know it is,
(Whether by deuiſe or no) the heauens can tell,
Is ſhe not then beholding to the man,
That brought her for this high good turne ſo farre?
Yes, and will Nobly him remunerate.

scene.stagedir: Flouriſh.
Enter the Emperor, Tamora, and her two ſons, with the Moore at one doore. Enter at the other doore Baſsianus and Lauinia with others

speech.speaker: Sat.
speech.line: So Baſsianus, you haue plaid your prize,
God giue you ioy ſir of your Gallant Bride.

speech.speaker: Baſs.
speech.line: And you of yours my Lord: I ſay no more,
Nor wiſh no leſſe, and ſo I take my leaue.

speech.speaker: Sat.
speech.line: Traytor, if Rome haue law, or we haue power,
Thou and thy Faƈtion ſhall repent this Rape.

speech.speaker: Baſs.
speech.line: Rape call you it my Lord, to ceaſe my owne,
My true betrothed Loue, and now my wife?
But let the lawes of Rome determine all,
Meane while I am poſſeſt of that is mine.

speech.speaker: Sat.
speech.line: ’Tis good ſir: you are very ſhort with vs,
But if we liue, weele be as ſharpe with you.

speech.speaker: Baſſ.
speech.line: My Lord, what I haue done as beſt I may,
Anſwere I muſt, and ſhall do with my life,
Onely thus much I giue your Grace to know,
By all the duties that I owe to Rome,
This Noble Gentleman Lord Titus heere,
Is in opinion and in honour wrong’d,
That in the reſcue of Lauinia,
With his owne hand did ſlay his youngeſt Son,
In zeale to you, and highly mou’d to wrath.
To be controul’d in that he frankly gaue:
Receiue him then to fauour Saturnine,
That hath expre’ſt himſelfe in all his deeds,
A Father and a friend to thee, and Rome.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Prince Baſsianus leaue to plead my Deeds,
’Tis thou, and thoſe, that haue diſhonoured me,
Rome and the righteous heauens be my iudge,
How I haue lou’d and Honour’d Saturnine.

speech.speaker: Tam.
speech.line: My worthy Lord if euer Tamora,
Were gracious in thoſe Princely eyes of thine,
Then heare me ſpeake indifferently for all:
And at my ſute (ſweet) pardon what is paſt.

speech.speaker: Satu.
speech.line: What Madam, be diſhonoured openly,
And baſely put it vp without reuenge?

speech.speaker: Tam.
speech.line: Not ſo my Lord,
The Gods of Rome fore-fend,
I ſhould be Authour to diſhonour you.
But on mine honour dare, I vndertake
For good Lord Titus innocence in all:
Whoſe fury not diſſembled ſpeakes his griefes:
Then at my ſute looke graciouſly on him,
Looſe not ſo noble a friend on vaine ſuppoſe,
Nor with ſowre lookes afﬂiƈt his gentle heart.
My Lord, be rul’d by me, be wonne at laſt,
Diſſemble all your griefes and diſcontents,
You are but newly planted in your Throne,
Leaſt then the people, and Patricians too,
Vpon a iuſt ſuruey take Titus part,
And ſo ſupplant vs for ingratitude,
Which Rome reputes to be a hainous ſinne.
Yeeld at intreats, and then let me alone:
Ile ﬁnde a day to maſſacre them all,
And race their faƈion, and their familie,
The cruell Father, and his trayt’rous ſonnes,
To whom I ſued for my deare ſonnes life.
And make them know what ’tis to let a Queene.
Kneele in the ſtreetes, and beg for grace in vaine.
Come, come, ſweet Emperour, (come Andronicus)
Take vp this good old man, and cheere the heart,
That dies in tempeſt of thy angry frowne.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Riſe Titus, riſe,
My Empreſſe hath preuail’d.

speech.speaker: Titus.
speech.line: I thanke your Maieſtie,
And her my Lord.
Theſe words, theſe lookes,
Infuſe new life in me.

speech.speaker: Tamo.
speech.line: Titus, I am incorparate in Rome,
A Roman now adopted happily.
And muſt aduiſe the Emperour for his good,
This day all quarrels die Andronicus.
And let it be mine honour good my Lord,
That I haue reconcil’d your friends and you.
For you Prince Baſsianus, I haue paſt
My word and promiſe to the Emperour,
That you will be more milde and traƈtable.
And feare not Lords:
And you Lauinia,
By my aduiſe all humbled on your knees,
You ſhall aske pardon of his Maieſtie.

speech.speaker: Son.
speech.line: We dœ,
And vow to heauen, and to his Highnes,
That what we did, was mildly, as we might,
Tendring our ſiſters honour and our owne.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: That on mine honour heere I do proteſt.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Away and talke not, trouble vs no more.

speech.speaker: Tamora.
speech.line: Nay, nay,
Sweet Emperour, we muſt all be friends,
The Tribune and his Nephews kneele for grace,
I will not be denied, ſweet hart looke back.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Marcus,
For thy ſake and thy brothers heere,
And at my louely Tamora’s intreats,
I dœ remit theſe young mens haynous faults.
Stand vp: Lauinia, though you leﬅ me like a churle,
I found a friend, and ſure as death I ſware,
I would not part a Batchellour from the Prieſt.
Come, if the Emperours Court can feaſt two Brides,
You are my gueſt Lauinia, and your friends:
This day ſhall be a Loue-day Tamora.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: To morrow and it pleaſe your Maieſtie,
To hunt the Panther and the Hart with me,
With horne and Hound,
Weele giue your Grace Bon iour.

speech.speaker: Satur
speech.line: Be it ſo Titus, and Gramercy to.Exeunt.

scene.stagedir: Flouriſh. Enter Aaron alone.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: Now climbeth Tamora Olympus toppe,
Safe out of Fortunes ſhot, and ſits aloſt,
Secure of Thunders cracke or lightning ﬂaſh,
Aduanc’d about pale enuies threatning reach:
As when the golden Sunne ſalutes the morne,
And hauing gilt the Ocean with his beames,
Gallops the Zodiacke in his gliſtering Coach,
And ouer-lookes the higheſt piering hills:
So Tamora
Vpon her wit doth earthly honour waite,
And vertue ſtoopes and trembles at her frowne.
Then Aaron arme thy hart, and ﬁt thy thoughts,
To mount aloſt with thy Emperiall Miſtris,
And mount her pitch, whom thou in triumph long
Haſt priſoner held, fettred in amorous chaines,
And faſter bound to Aarons charming eyes,
Then is Prometheus ti’de to Caucaſus.
Away with ſlauiſh weedes, and idle thoughts,
I will be bright and ſhine in Pearle and Gold,
To waite vpon this new made Empreſſe.
To waite ſaid I? To wanton with this Queene,
This Goddeſſe, this Semirimis, this Queene.
This Syren, that will charme Romes Saturnine,
And ſee his ſhipwracke, and his Common weales.
Hollo, what ſtorme is this?

scene.stagedir: Enter Chiron and Demetrius brauing.

speech.speaker: Dem.
speech.line: Chiron thy yeres wants wit, thy wit wants edge
And manners to intru’d where I am grac’d,
And may for ought thou know’ſt affeƈted be.

speech.speaker: Chi.
speech.line: Demetrius, thou doo’ſt ouer-weene in all,
And ſo in this, to beare me downe with braues,
’Tis not the difference of a yeere or two
Makes me leſſe gracious, or thee more fortunate:
I am as able, and as ﬁt, as thou,
To ſerue, and to deſerue my Miſtris grace,
And that my ſword vpon thee ſhall approue,
And plead my paſſions for Lauinia's loue.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: Clubs, clubs, theſe louers will not keep the peace.

speech.speaker: Dem.
speech.line: Why Boy, although our mother (vnaduiſed)
Gaue you a daunſing Rapier by your ſide,
Are you ſo deſperate growne to threat your friends?
Gœ too: haue your Lath glued within your ſheath,
Till you know better how to handle it.

speech.speaker: Chi.
speech.line: Meane while ſir, with the little skill I haue,
Full well ſhalt thou perceiue how much I dare.

speech.speaker: Deme
speech.line: I Boy, grow ye ſo braue?They drawe.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: Why how now Lords?
So nere the Emperours Pallace dare you draw,
And maintaine ſuch a quarrell openly?
Full well I wote, the ground of all this grudge.
I would not for a million of Gold,
The cauſe were knowne to them it moſt concernes.
Nor would your noble mother for much more
Be ſo diſhonored in the Court of Rome:
For ſhame put vp.

speech.speaker: Deme.
speech.line: Not I, till I haue ſheath’d
My rapier in his boſome, and withall
Thruſt theſe reprochfull ſpeeches downe his throat,
That he hath breath’d in my diſhonour heere.

speech.speaker: Chi.
speech.line: For that I am prepar’d, and full reſolu’d,
Foule ſpoken Coward,
That thundreſt with thy tongue,
And with thy weapon nothing dar’ſt performe.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: A way I ſay.
Now by the Gods that warlike Gothes adore,
This pretty brabble will vndoo vs all:
Why Lords, and thinke you not how dangerous
It is to ſet vpon a Princes right?
What is Lauinia then become ſo looſe,
Or Baſsianus ſo degenerate,
That for her loue ſuch quarrels may be broacht,
Without controulement, Iuſtice, or reuenge?
Young Lords beware, and ſhould the Empreſſe know,
This diſcord ground, the muſicke would not pleaſe.

speech.speaker: Chi.
speech.line: I care not I, knew ſhe and all the world,
I loue Lauinia more then all the world.

speech.speaker: Demet.
speech.line: Youngling,
Learne thou to make ſome meaner choiſe,
Lauinia is thine elder brothers hope.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: Why are ye mad? Or know ye not in Rome,
How furious and impatient they be,
And cannot brooke Competitors in loue?
I tell you Lords, you dœ but plot your deaths,
By this deuiſe.

speech.speaker: Chi.
speech.line: Aaron, a thouſand deaths would I propoſe,
To atchieue her whom I do loue.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: To atcheiue her, how?

speech.speaker: Deme.
speech.line: Why, mak’ſt thou it ſo ſtrange?
Shee is a woman, therefore may be woo’d,
Shee is a woman, therfore may be wonne,
Shee is Lauinia therefore muſt be lou’d.
What man, more water glideth by the Mill
Then wots the Miller of, and eaſie it is
Of a cut loafe to ſteale a ſhiue we know:
Though Baſsianus be the Emperours brother,
Better then he haue worne Vulcans badge.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: I, and as good as Saturninus may.

speech.speaker: Deme.
speech.line: Then why ſhould he diſpaire that knowes to court it
With words, faire lookes, and liberality:
What haſt not thou full oﬅen ſtrucke a Dœ,
And borne her cleanly by the Keepers noſe?

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: Why then it ſeemes ſome certaine ſnatch or ſo
Would ſerue your turnes.

speech.speaker: Chi.
speech.line: I ſo the turne were ſerued.

speech.speaker: Deme.
speech.line: Aaron thou haſt hit it.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: Would you had hit it too,
Then ſhould not we be tir’d with this adoo:
Why harke yee, harke yee, and are you ſuch fooles,
To ſquare for this? Would it offend you then?

speech.speaker: Chi.
speech.line: Faith not me.

speech.speaker: Deme.
speech.line: Nor me, ſo I were one.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: For ſhame be friends, & ioyne for that you iar:
’Tis pollicie, and ſtratageme muſt dœ
That you affeƈt, and ſo muſt you reſolue,
That what you cannot as you would atcheiue,
You muſt perforce accompliſh as you may:
Take this of me, Lucrece was not more chaſt
Then this Lauinia, Baſsianus loue,
A ſpeedier courſe this lingring languiſhment
Muſt we purſue, and I haue found the path:
My Lords, a ſolemne hunting is in hand.
There will the louely Roman Ladies troope:
The Forreſt walkes are wide and ſpacious,
And many vnfrequented plots there are,
Fitted by kinde for rape and villanie:
Single you thither then this dainty Dœ,
And ſtrike her home by force, if not by words:
This way or not at all, ſtand you in hope.
Come, come, our Empreſſe with her ſacred wit
To villainie and vengance conſecrate,
Will we acquaint with all that we intend,
And ſhe ſhall ﬁle our engines with aduiſe,
That will not ſuffer you to ſquare your ſelues,
But to your wiſhes height aduance you both.
The Emperours Court is like the houſe of Fame,
The pallace full of tongues, of eyes, of eares:
The Woods are ruthleſſe, dreadfull, deafe, and dull:
There ſpeake, and ſtrike braue Boyes, & take your turnes.
There ſerue your luſts, ſhadow’d from heauens eye,
And reuell in Lauinia’s Treaſurie.

speech.speaker: Chi.
speech.line: Thy counſell Lad ſmells of no cowardiſe.

speech.speaker: Deme.
speech.line: Sit fas aut nefas, till I ﬁnde the ſtreames,
To coole this heat, a Charme to calme their ﬁts,
Per Stigia per manes Vehor.Exeunt.

scene.stagedir: Enter Titus Andronicus and his three ſonnes, making a noyſe with hounds and hornes, and Marcus

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: The hunt is vp, the morne is bright and gray,
The ﬁelds are fragrant, and the Woods are greene,
Vncouple heere, and let vs make a bay,
And wake the Emperour, and his louely Bride,
And rouze the Prince, and ring a hunters peale,
That all the Court may eccho with the noyſe.
Sonnes let it be your charge, as it is ours,
To attend the Emperours perſon carefully:
I haue bene troubled in my ſleepe this night,
But dawning day new comfort hath inſpir’d.

scene.stagedir: Winde Hornes.
Heere a cry of houndes, and winde hornes in a peale, then Enter Saturninus, Tamora, Baſſianus, Lauinia, Chiron, Demetrius, and their Attendants

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: Many good morrowes to your Maieſtie,
Madam to you as many and as good.
I promiſed your Grace, a Hunters peale.

speech.speaker: Satur.
speech.line: And you haue rung it luſtily my Lords,
Somewhat to earely for new married Ladies.

speech.speaker: Baſs.
speech.line: Lauinia, how ſay you?

speech.speaker: Laui.
speech.line: I ſay no:
I haue bene awake two houres and more.

speech.speaker: Satur.
speech.line: Come on then, horſe and Chariots let vs haue,
And to our ſport: Madam, now ſhall ye ſee,
Our Romaine hunting.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: I haue dogges my Lord,
Will rouze the proudeſt Panther in the Chaſe,
And clime the higheſt Promontary top.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: And I haue horſe will follow where the game
Makes way, and runnes likes Swallowes ore the plaine

speech.speaker: Deme.
speech.line: Chiron we hunt not we, with Horſe nor Hound
But hope to plucke a dainty Dœ to ground.Exeunt

scene.stagedir: Enter Aaron alone.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: He that had wit, would thinke that I had none,
To bury ſo much Gold vnder a Tree,
And neuer aﬅer to inherit it.
Let him that thinks of me ſo abieƈtly,
Know that this Gold muſt coine a ſtratageme,
Which cunningly effeƈted, will beget
A very excellent peece of villany;
And ſo repoſe ſweet Gold for their vnreſt,
That haue their Almes out of the Empreſſe Cheſt.

scene.stagedir: Enter Tamora to the Moore.

speech.speaker: Tamo.
speech.line: My louely Aaron,
Wherefore look’ſt thou ſad,
When euery thing doth make a Gleefull boaſt?
The Birds chaunt melody on euery buſh,
The Snake lies rolled in the chearefull Sunne,
The greene leaues quiuer, with the cooling winde,
And make a cheker’d ſhadow on the ground:
Vnder their ſweete ſhade, Aaron let vs ſit,
And whil’ſt the babling Eccho mock’s the Hounds,
Replying ſhrilly to the well tun’d-Hornes,
As if a double hunt were heard at once,
Let vs ſit downe, and marke their yelping noyſe:
And aﬅer conﬂiƈt, ſuch as was ſuppos’d.
The wandring Prince and Dido once enioy’d,
When with a happy ſtorme they were ſurpris’d,
And Curtain’d with a Counſaile-keeping Caue,
We may each wreathed in the others armes,
(Our paſtimes done) poſſeſſe a Golden ſlumber,
Whiles Hounds and Hornes, and ſweet Melodious Birds
Be vnto vs, as is a Nurſes Song
Of Lullabie, to bring her Babe aſleepe.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: Madame,
Though Venus gouerne your deſires,
Saturne is Dominator ouer mine:
What ſigniﬁes my deadly ſtanding eye,
My ſilence, and my Cloudy Melancholie,
My ﬂeece of Woolly haire, that now vncurles,
Euen as an Adder when ſhe doth vnrowle
To do ſome fatall execution?
No Madam, theſe are no Veneriall ſignes,
Vengeance is in my heart, death in my hand,
Blood, and reuenge, are Hammering in my head.
Harke Tamora, the Empreſſe of my Soule,
Which neuer hopes more heauen, then reſts in thee,
This is the day of Doome for Baſsianus;
His Philomel muſt looſe her tongue to day,
Thy Sonnes make Pillage of her Chaſtity,
And waſh their hands in Baſſianus blood.
Seeſt thou this Letter, take it vp I pray thee,
And giue the King this fatall plotted Scrowle,
Now queſtion me no more, we are eſpied,
Heere comes a parcell of our hopefull Booty,
Which dreads not yet their liues deſtruƈtion.

scene.stagedir: Enter Baſſianus and Lauinia.

speech.speaker: Tamo.
speech.line: Ah my ſweet Moore:
Sweeter to me then life.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: No more great Empreſſe, Baſſianus comes,
Be croſſe with him, and Ile gœ fetch thy Sonnes
To backe thy quarrell what ſo ere they be.

speech.speaker: Baſſi.
speech.line: Whom haue we heere?
Romes Royall Empreſſe,
Vnfurniſht of our well beſeeming troope?
Or is it Dian habited like her,
Who hath abandoned her holy Groues,
To ſee the generall Hunting in this Forreſt?

speech.speaker: Tamo.
speech.line: Sawcie controuler of our priuate ſteps:
Had I the power, that ſome ſay Dian had,
Thy Temples ſhould be planted preſently.
With Hornes, as was Aƈteons, and the Hounds
Should driue vpon his new transformed limbes,
Vnmannerly Intruder as thou art.

speech.speaker: Laui.
speech.line: Vnder your patience gentle Empreſſe,
’Tis thought you haue a goodly giﬅ in Horning,
And to be doubted, that your Moore and you
Are ſingled forth to try experiments:
Ioue ſheild your husband from his Hounds to day,
’Tis pitty they ſhould take him for a Stag.

speech.speaker: Baſſi.
speech.line: Beleeue me Queene, your ſwarth Cymerion,
Doth make your Honour of his bodies Hue,
Spotted, deteſted, and abhominable.
Why are you ſequeſtred from all your traine?
Diſmounted from your Snow-white goodly Steed,
And wandred hither to an obſcure plot,
Accompanied with a barbarous Moore,
If foule deſire had not conduƈted you?

speech.speaker: Laui.
speech.line: And being intercepted in your ſport,
Great reaſon that my Noble Lord, be rated
For Saucineſſe, I pray you let vs hence,
And let her ioy her Rauen coloured loue,
This valley ﬁts the purpoſe paſſing well.

speech.speaker: Baſſi.
speech.line: The King my Brother ſhall haue notice of this.

speech.speaker: Laui.
speech.line: I, for theſe ſlips haue made him noted long,
Good King, to be ſo mightily abuſed.

speech.speaker: Tamora.
speech.line: Why I haue patience to endure all this?

scene.stagedir: Enter Chiron and Demetrius.

speech.speaker: Dem.
speech.line: How now deere Soueraigne
And our gracious Mother,
Why doth your Highnes looke ſo pale and wan?

speech.speaker: Tamo.
speech.line: Haue I not reaſon thinke you to looke pale.
Theſe two haue tic’d me hither to this place,
A barren, deteſted vale you ſee it is.
The Trees though Sommer, yet forlorne and leane,
Ore-come with Moſſe, and balefull Miſſelto.
Heere neuer ſhines the Sunne, heere nothing breeds,
Vnleſſe the nightly Owle, or fatall Rauen:
And when they ſhew’d me this abhorred pit,
They told me heere at dead time of the night,
A thouſand Fiends, a thouſand hiſſing Snakes,
Ten thouſand ſwelling Toades, as many Vrchins,
Would make ſuch fearefull and confuſed cries,
As any mortall body hearing it,
Should ſtraite fall mad, or elſe die ſuddenly.
No ſooner had they told this helliſh tale,
But ſtrait they told me they would binde me heere,
Vnto the body of a diſmall yew,
And leaue me to this miſerable death.
And then they call’d me foule Adultereſſe,
Laſciuious Goth, and all the bittereſt tearmes
That euer eare did heare to ſuch effeƈt.
And had you not by wondrous fortune come,
This vengeance on me had they executed:
Reuenge it, as you loue your Mothers life,
Or be ye not henceforth cal’d my Children.

speech.speaker: Dem
speech.line: This is a witneſſe that I am thy Sonne. ſtab him.

speech.speaker: Chi.
speech.line: And this for me,
Strook home to ſhew my ſtrength.

speech.speaker: Laui.
speech.line: I come Semeramis, nay Barbarous Tamora.
For no name ﬁts thy nature but thy owne.

speech.speaker: Tam.
speech.line: Giue me thy poyniard, you ſhal know my boyes
Your Mothers hand ſhall right your Mothers wrong.

speech.speaker: Deme.
speech.line: Stay Madam heere is more belongs to her,
Firſt thraſh the Corne, then aﬅer burne the ſtraw:
This Minion ſtood vpon her chaſtity,
Vpon her Nuptiall vow, her loyaltie.
And with that painted hope, braues your Mightineſſe,
And ſhall ſhe carry this vnto her graue?

speech.speaker: Chi.
speech.line: And if ſhe dœ,
I would I were an Eunuch,
Drag hence her husband to ſome ſecret hole,
And make his dead Trunke-Pillow to our luſt.

speech.speaker: Tamo.
speech.line: But when ye haue the hony we deſire,
Let not this Waſpe out-liue vs both to ſting.

speech.speaker: Chir.
speech.line: I warrant you Madam we will make that ſure:
Come Miſtris, now perforce we will enioy,
That nice-preſerued honeſty of yours.

speech.speaker: Laui.
speech.line: Oh Tamora, thou bear’ſt a woman face.

speech.speaker: Tamo.
speech.line: I will not heare her ſpeake, away with her.

speech.speaker: Laui.
speech.line: Sweet Lords intreat her heare me but a word.

speech.speaker: Demet.
speech.line: Liſten faire Madam, let it be your glory
To ſee her teares, but be your hart to them,
As vnrelenting ﬂint to drops of raine.

speech.speaker: Laui.
speech.line: When did the Tigers young-ones teach the dam?
O dœ not learne her wrath, ſhe taught it thee,
The milke thou ſuck’ſt from her did turne to Marble,
Euen at thy Teat thou had’ſt thy Tyranny,
Yet euery Mother breeds not Sonnes alike,
Do thou intreat her ſhew a woman pitty.

speech.speaker: Chiro.
speech.line: What,
Would’ſt thou haue me proue my ſelfe a baſtard?

speech.speaker: Laui.
speech.line: ’Tis true,
The Rauen doth not hatch a Larke,
Yet haue I heard, Oh could I ﬁnde it now,
The Lion mou’d with pitty, did indure
To haue his Princely pawes par’d all away.
Some ſay, that Rauens foſter forlorne children,
The whil’ſt their owne birds famiſh in their neſts:
Oh be to me though thy hard hart ſay no,
Nothing ſo kind but ſomething pittifull.

speech.speaker: Tamo.
speech.line: I know not what it meanes, away with her.

speech.speaker: Lauin.
speech.line: Oh let me teach thee for my Fathers ſake,
That gaue thee life when well he might haue ſlaine thee:
Be not obdurate, open thy deafe eares.

speech.speaker: Tamo.
speech.line: Had’ſt thou in perſon nere offended me.
Euen for his ſake am I pittileſſe:
Remember Boyes I powr’d forth teares in vaine,
To ſaue your brother from the ſacriﬁce,
But ﬁerce Andronicus would not relent,
Therefore away with her, and vſe her as you will,
The worſe to her, the better lou’d of me.

speech.speaker: Laui.
speech.line: Oh Tamora,
Be call’d a gentle Queene,
And with thine owne hands kill me in this place,
For ’tis not life that I haue beg’d ſo long,
Poore I was ſlaine, when Baſſianus dy’d.

speech.speaker: Tam.
speech.line: What beg’ſt thou then? fond woman let me go?

speech.speaker: Laui.
speech.line: ’Tis preſent death I beg, and one thing more,
That womanhood denies my tongue to tell:
Oh keepe me from their worſe then killing luſt,
And tumble me into ſome loathſome pit,
Where neuer mans eye may behold my body,
Dœ this, and be a charitable murderer.

speech.speaker: Tam.
speech.line: So ſhould I rob my ſweet Sonnes of their fee,
No let them ſatiſﬁe their luſt on thee.

speech.speaker: Deme.
speech.line: Away,
For thou haſt ſtaid vs heere too long.

speech.speaker: Lauinia.
speech.line: No Grace,
No womanhood? Ah beaſtly creature,
The blot and enemy to our generall name,
Confuſion fall—

speech.speaker: Chi.
speech.line: Nay then Ile ſtop your mouth
Bring thou her husband,
This is the Hole where Aaron bid vs hide him.

speech.speaker: Tam.
speech.line: Farewell my Sonnes, ſee that you make her ſure,
Nere let my heart know merry cheere indeed,
Till all the Andronici be made away:
Now will I hence to ſeeke my louely Moore,
And let my ſpleenefull Sonnes this Trull deﬂoure.Exit.

scene.stagedir: Enter Aaron with two of Titus Sonnes.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: Come on my Lords, the better foote before,
Straight will I bring you to the lothſome pit,
Where I eſpied the Panther faſt aſleepe.

speech.speaker: Quin.
speech.line: My ſight is very dull what ere it bodes.

speech.speaker: Marti.
speech.line: And mine I promiſe you, were it not for ſhame,
Well could I leaue our ſport to ſleepe a while.

speech.speaker: Quin.
speech.line: What art thou fallen?
What ſubtile Hole is this,
Whoſe mouth is couered with Rude growing Briers,
Vpon whoſe leaues are drops of new-ſhed-blood,
As freſh as mornings dew diſtil’d on ﬂowers,
A very fatall place it ſeemes to me:
Speake Brother haſt thou hurt thee with the fall?

speech.speaker: Martius.
speech.line: Oh Brother,
With the diſmal’ſt obieƈt
That euer eye with ſight made heart lament.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: Now will I fetch the King to ﬁnde them heere,
That he thereby may haue a likely geſſe,
How theſe were they that made away his Brother.

scene.stagedir: Exit Aaron.

speech.speaker: Marti.
speech.line: Why doſt not comfort me and helpe me out,
From this vnhallow’d and blood-ſtained Hole?

speech.speaker: Quintus.
speech.line: I am ſurpriſed with an vncouth feare,
A chilling ſweat ore-runs my trembling ioynts,
My heart ſuſpeƈts more then mine eie can ſee.

speech.speaker: Marti.
speech.line: To proue thou haſt a true diuining heart,
Aaron and thou looke downe into this den,
And ſee a fearefull ſight of blood and death.

speech.speaker: Quintus.
speech.line: Aaron is gone,
And my compaſſionate heart
Will not permit mine eyes once to behold
The thing where at it trembles by ſurmiſe:
Oh tell me how it is, for nere till now
Was I a child to feare I know not what.

speech.speaker: Marti.
speech.line: Lord Baſſianus lies embrewed heere,
All on a heape like to the ſlaughtred Lambe,
In this deteſted, darke, blood-drinking pit.

speech.speaker: Quin.
speech.line: If it be darke, how dooſt thou know ’tis he?

speech.speaker: Mart.
speech.line: Vpon his bloody ﬁnger he doth weare
A precious Ring, that lightens all the Hole:
Which like a Taper in ſome Monument,
Doth ſhine vpon the dead mans earthly cheekes,
And ſhewes the ragged intrailes of the pit:
So pale did ſhine the Moone on Piramus,
When he by night lay bath’d in Maiden blood:
O Brother helpe me with thy fainting hand.
If feare hath made thee faint, as mee it hath,
Out of this fell deuouring receptacle,
As hatefull as Ocitus miſtie mouth.

speech.speaker: Quint.
speech.line: Reach me thy hand, that I may helpe thee out,
Or wanting ſtrength to dœ thee ſo much good,
I may be pluckt into the ſwallowing wombe,
Of this deepe pit, poore Baſsianus graue:
I haue no ſtrength to plucke thee to the brinke.

speech.speaker: Martius.
speech.line: Nor I no ſtrength to clime without thy help.

speech.speaker: Quin.
speech.line: Thy hand once more, I will not looſe againe,
Till thou art heere aloſt, or I below,
Thou can’ſt not come to me, I come to thee.Boths fall in.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Emperour, Aaron the Moore.

speech.speaker: Satur.
speech.line: Along with me, Ile ſee what hole is heere,
And what he is that now is leapt into it.
Say, who art thou that lately did’ſt deſcend,
Into this gaping hollow of the earth?

speech.speaker: Marti.
speech.line: The vnhappie ſonne of old Andronicus,
Brought hither in a moſt vnluckie houre,
To ﬁnde thy brother Baſsianus dead.

speech.speaker: Satur.
speech.line: My brother dead? I know thou doſt but ieſt,
He and his Lady both are at the Lodge,
Vpon the North-ſide of this pleaſant Chaſe,
’Tis not an houre ſince I leﬅ him there.

speech.speaker: Marti.
speech.line: We know not where you leﬅ him all aliue,
But out alas, heere haue we found him dead.

scene.stagedir: Enter Tamora, Andronicus, and Lucius.

speech.speaker: Tamo.
speech.line: Where is my Lord the King?

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Heere Tamora, though grieu’d with killing griefe.

speech.speaker: Tam.
speech.line: Where is thy brother Baſsianus?

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Now to the bottome doſt thou ſearch my wound,
Poore Baſsianus heere lies murthered.

speech.speaker: Tam.
speech.line: Then all too late I bring this fatall writ,
The complot of this timeleſſe Tragedie,
And wonder greatly that mans face can fold,
In pleaſing ſmiles ſuch murderous Tyrannie.
And if we miſſe to meete him hanſomely,
Sweet huntſman, Baſſianus ’tis we meane,
Dœ thou ſo much as dig the graue for him,

line.italic: Thou know’ſt our meaning, looke for thy reward
Among the Nettles at the Elder tree:
Which ouer-ſhades the mouth of that ſame pit:
Where we decreed to bury Baſſianuss
Dœ this and purchaſe vs thy laſting friends.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Oh Tamora, was euer heard the like?
This is the pit, and this the Elder tree,
Looke ſirs, if you can ﬁnde the huntſman out,
That ſhould haue murthered Baſsianus heere.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: My gracious Lord heere is the bag of Gold.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Two of thy whelpes, fell Curs of bloody kind
Haue heere bereſt my brother of his life:
Sirs drag them from the pit vnto the priſon,
There let them bide vntill we haue deuis’d
Some neuer heard-of tortering paine for them.

speech.speaker: Tamo.
speech.line: What are they in this pit,
Oh wondrous thing!
How eaſily murder is diſcouered?

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: High Emperour, vpon my feeble knee,
I beg this boone, with teares, not lightly ſhed,
That this fell fault of my accurſed Sonnes,
Accurſed, if the faults be prou’d in them.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: If it be prou’d? you ſee it is apparant,
Who found this Letter, Tamora was it you?

speech.speaker: Tamora.
speech.line: Andronicus himſelfe did take it vp.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: I did my Lord,
Yet let me be their baile,
For by my Fathers reuerent Tombe I vow
They ſhall be ready at your Highnes will,
To anſwere their ſuſpition with their liues.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Thou ſhalt not baile them, ſee thou follow me:
Some bring the murthered body, ſome the murtherers,
Let them not ſpeake a word, the guilt is plaine,
For by my ſoule, were there worſe end then death,
That end vpon them ſhould be executed.

speech.speaker: Tamo.
speech.line: Andronicus I will entreat the King,
Feare not thy Sonnes, they ſhall do well enough.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Come Lucius come,
Stay not to talke with them.Exeunt.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Empreſſe Sonnes, with Lauinia, her hands cut off and her tongue cut out, and rauiſht

speech.speaker: Deme.
speech.line: So now gœ tell and if thy tongue can ſpeake,
Who t’was that cut thy tongue and rauiſht thee.

speech.speaker: Chi.
speech.line: Write downe thy mind, bewray thy meaning ſo,
And if thy ſtumpes will let thee play the Scribe.

speech.speaker: Dem.
speech.line: See how with ſignes and tokens ſhe can ſcowle.

speech.speaker: Chi.
speech.line: Gœ home,
Call for ſweet water, waſh thy hands.

speech.speaker: Dem.
speech.line: She hath no tongue to call, nor hands to waſh.
And ſo let’s leaue her to her ſilent walkes.

speech.speaker: Chi.
speech.line: And t’were my cauſe, I ſhould gœ hang my ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Dem.
speech.line: If thou had’ſt hands to helpe thee knit the cord.
speech.stagedir: Enter Marcus from hunting, to Lauinia.
speech.line: Who is this, my Neece that ﬂies away ſo faſt?
Coſen a word, where is your husband?
If I do dreame, would all my wealth would wake me;
If I dœ wake, ſome Planet ſtrike me downe,
That I may ſlumber in eternall ſleepe.
Speake gentle Neece, what ſterne vngentle hands
Hath lopt, and hew’d, and made thy body bare
Of her two branches, thoſe ſweet Ornaments
Whoſe circkling ſhadowes, Kings haue ſought to ſleep in
And might not gaine ſo great a happines
As halfe thy Loue: Why dooſt not ſpeake to me?
Alas, a Crimſon riuer of warme blood,
Like to a bubling fountaine ſtir’d with winde,
Doth riſe and fall betweene thy Roſed lips,
Comming and going with thy hony breath.
But ſure ſome Tereus hath deﬂoured thee,
And leaſt thou ſhould’ſt deteƈt them, cut thy tongue.
Ah, now thou turn’ſt away thy face for ſhame:
And notwithſtanding all this loſſe of blood,
As from a Conduit with their iſſuing Spouts,
Yet dœ thy cheekes looke red as Titans face,
Bluſhing to be encountred with a Cloud,
Shall I ſpeake for thee? ſhall I ſay ’tis ſo?
Oh that I knew thy hart, and knew the beaſt
That I might raile at him to eaſe my mind.
Sorrow concealed, like an Ouen ſtopt.
Doth burne the hart to Cinders where it is.
Faire Philomela ſhe but loſt her tongue,
And in a tedious Sampler ſowed her minde.
But louely Neece, that meane is cut from thee,
A craﬅier Tereus haſt thou met withall,
And he hath cut thoſe pretty ﬁngers off,
That could haue better ſowed then Philomel.
Oh had the monſter ſeene thoſe Lilly hands,
Tremble like Aſpen leaues vpon a Lute,
And make the ſilken ſtrings delight to kiſſe them,
He would not then haue toucht them for his life.
Or had he heard the heauenly Harmony,
Which that ſweet tongue hath made:
He would haue dropt his knife and fell aſleepe,
As Cerberus at the Thracian Pœts feete.
Come, let vs gœ, and make thy father blinde,
For ſuch a ſight will blinde a fathers eye.
One houres ſtorme will drowne the fragrant meades,
What, will whole months of teares thy Fathers eyes?
Dœ not draw backe, for we will mourne with thee:
Oh could our mourning eaſe thy miſery.Exeunt

scene.stagedir: Enter the Iudges and Senatours with Titus two ſonnes bound, paſſing on the Stage to the place of execution, and Titus going before pleading

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: Heare me graue fathers, noble Tribunes ſtay,
For pitty of mine age, whoſe youth was ſpent
In dangerous warres, whilſt you ſecurely ſlept:
For all my blood in Romes great quarrell ſhed,
For all the froſty nights that I haue watcht,
And for theſe bitter teares, which now you ſee,
Filling the aged wrinkles in my cheekes,
Be pittifull to my condemned Sonnes,
Whoſe ſoules is not corrupted as ’tis thought:
For two and twenty ſonnes I neuer wept,
Becauſe they died in honours loﬅy bed.
speech.stagedir: Andronicus lyeth downe, and the Iudges paſſe by him.
speech.line: For theſe, Tribunes, in the duſt I write
My harts deepe languor, and my ſoules ſad teares:
Let my teares ſtanch the earths drie appetite.
My ſonnes ſweet blood, will make it ſhame and bluſh:
O earth! I will be friend thee more with raineExeunt
That ſhall diſtill from theſe two ancient ruines,
Then youthfull Aprill ſhall with all his ſhowres
In ſummers drought: Ile drop vpon thee ſtill,
In Winter with warme teares Ile melt the ſnow,
And keepe eternall ſpring time on thy face,
So thou refuſe to drinke my deare ſonnes blood.
speech.stagedir: Enter Lucius, with his weapon drawne.
speech.line: Oh reuerent Tribunes, oh gentle aged men,
Vnbinde my ſonnes, reuerſe the doome of death,
And let me ſay (that neuer wept before)
My teares are now preualing Oratours.

speech.speaker: Lu.
speech.line: Oh noble father, you lament in vaine,
The Tribunes heare not, no man is by,
And you recount your ſorrowes to a ſtone.

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: Ah Lucius for thy brothers let me plead,
Graue Tribunes, once more I intreat of you.

speech.speaker: Lu.
speech.line: My gracious Lord, no Tribune heares you ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: Why ’tis no matter man, if they did heare
They would not marke me: oh if they did heare
They would not pitty me.
Therefore I tell my ſorrowes bootles to the ſtones.
Who though they cannot anſwere my diſtreſſe,
Yet in ſome ſort they are better then the Tribunes,
For that they will not intercept my tale;
When I dœ weepe, they humbly at my feete
Receiue my teares, and ſeeme to weepe with me,
And were they but attired in graue weedes,
Rome could afford no Tribune like to theſe.
A ſtone is as ſoﬅ waxe,
Tribunes more hard then ſtones:
A ſtone is ſilent, and offendeth not,
And Tribunes with their tongues doome men to death.
But wherefore ſtand’ſt thou with thy weapon drawne?

speech.speaker: Lu.
speech.line: To reſcue my two brothers from their death,
For which attempt the Iudges haue pronounc’ſt
My euerlaſting doome of baniſhment.

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: O happy man, they haue befriended thee:
Why fooliſh Lucius, doſt thou not perceiue
That Rome is but a wildernes of Tigers?
Tigers muſt pray, and Rome affords no prey
But me and mine: how happy art thou then,
From theſe deuourers to be baniſhed?
But who comes with our brother Marcus heere?

scene.stagedir: Enter Marcus and Lauinia.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Titus, prepare thy noble eyes to weepe,
Or if not ſo, thy noble heart to breake:
I bring conſuming ſorrow to thine age.

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: Will it conſume me? Let me ſee it then.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: This was thy daughter.

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: Why Marcus ſo ſhe is.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Aye me this obieƈt kils me.

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: Faint-harted boy, ariſe and looke vpon her,
Speake Lauinia, what accurſed hand
Hath made thee handleſſe in thy Fathers ſight?
What foole hath added water to the Sea?
Or brought a faggot to bright burning Troy?
My griefe was at the height before thou cam’ſt,
And now like Nylus it diſdaineth bounds:
Giue me a ſword, Ile chop off my hands too,
For they haue fought for Rome, and all in vaine:
And they haue nur’ſt this wœ,
In feeding life:
In booteleſſe prayer haue they bene held vp,
And they haue ſeru’d me to effeƈtleſſe vſe.
Now all the ſeruice I require of them,
Is that the one will helpe to cut the other:
’Tis well Lauinia, that thou haſt no hands,
For hands to do Rome ſeruice, is but vaine.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: Speake gentle ſiſter, who hath martyr’d thee?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: O that delightfull engine of her thoughts,
That blab’d them with ſuch pleaſing eloquence,
Is torne from forth that pretty hollow cage,
Where like a ſweet mellodius bird it ſung,
Sweet varied notes inchanting euery eare.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: Oh ſay thou for her,
Who hath done this deed?

speech.speaker: Marc.
speech.line: Oh thus I found her ſtraying in the Parke,
Seeking to hide herſelfe as doth the Deare
That hath receiude ſome vnrecuring wound.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: It was my Deare,
And he that wounded her,
Hath hurt me more, then had he kild me dead:
For now I ſtand as one vpon a Rocke,
Inuiron’d with a wilderneſſe of Sea.
Who markes the waxing tide,
Grow waue by waue,
Expeƈting euer when ſome enuious ſurge,
Will in his briniſh bowels ſwallow him.
This way to death my wretched ſonnes are gone:
Heere ſtands my other ſonne, a baniſht man,
And heere my brother weeping at my wœs.
But that which giues my ſoule the greateſt ſpurne,
Is deere Lauinia, deerer then my ſoule.
Had I but ſeene thy piƈture in this plight,
It would haue madded me. What ſhall I dœ?
Now I behold thy liuely body ſo?
Thou haſt no hands to wipe away thy teares,
Nor tongue to tell me who hath martyr’d thee:
Thy husband he is dead, and for his death
Thy brothers are condemn’d, and dead by this.
Looke Marcus, ah ſonne Lucius looke on her:
When I did name her brothers, then freſh teares
Stood on her cheekes, as doth the hony dew,
Vpon a gathred Lillie almoſt withered.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Perchance ſhe weepes becauſe they kil’d her husband,
Perchance becauſe ſhe knowes him innocent.

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: If they did kill thy husband then be ioyfull,
Becauſe the law hath tane reuenge on them.
No, no, they would not dœ ſo foule a deede,
Witnes the ſorrow that their ſiſter makes.
Gentle Lauinia let me kiſſe thy lips,
Or make ſome ſignes how I may do thee eaſe:
Shall thy good Vncle, and thy brother Lucius,
And thou and I ſit round about ſome Fountaine,
Looking all downewards to behold our cheekes
How they are ſtain’d in meadowes, yet not dry
With miery ſlime leﬅ on them by a ﬂood:
And in the Fountaine ſhall we gaze ſo long,
Till the freſh taſte be taken from that cleerenes,
And made a brine pit with our bitter teares?
Or ſhall we cut away our hands like thine?
Or ſhall we bite our tongues, and in dumbe ſhewes
Paſſe the remainder of our hatefull dayes?
What ſhall we dœ? Let vs that haue our tongues
Plot ſome deuiſe of further miſeries
To make vs wondred at in time to come.

speech.speaker: Lu.
speech.line: Sweet Father ceaſe your teares, for at your griefe
See how my wretched ſiſter ſobs and weeps.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Patience deere Neece, good Titus drie thine eyes.

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: Ah Marcus, Marcus, Brother well I wot,
Thy napkin cannot drinke a teare of mine,
For thou poore man haſt drown’d it with thine owne.

speech.speaker: Lu.
speech.line: Ah my Lauinia I will wipe thy cheekes.

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: Marke Marcus marke, I vnderſtand her ſignes,
Had ſhe a tongue to ſpeake, now would ſhe ſay
That to her brother which I ſaid to thee.
His Napkin with her true teares all bewet,
Can do no ſeruice on her ſorrowfull cheekes.
Oh what a ſimpathy of wœ is this!
As farre from helpe as Limbo is from bliſſe,

scene.stagedir: Enter Aron the Moore alone.

speech.speaker: Moore.
speech.line: Titus Andronicus, my Lord the Emperour,
Sends thee this word, that if thou loue thy ſonnes,
Let Marcus, Lucius, or thy ſelfe old Titus,
Or any one of you, chop off your hand,
And ſend it to the King: he for the ſame,
Will ſend thee hither both thy ſonnes aliue,
And that ſhall be the ranſome for their fault.

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: Oh gracious Emperour, oh gentle Aaron.
Did euer Rauen ſing ſo like a Larke,
That giues ſweet tydings of the Sunnes vpriſe?
With all my heart, Ile ſend the Emperour my hand,
Good Aron wilt thou help to chop it off?

speech.speaker: Lu.
speech.line: Stay Father, for that noble hand of thine,
That hath throwne downe ſo many enemies,
Shall not be ſent: my hand will ſerue the turne,
My youth can better ſpare my blood then you,
And therfore mine ſhall ſaue my brothers liues.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Which of your hands hath not defended Rome,
And rear’d aloſt the bloody Battleaxe,
Writing deſtruƈtion on the enemies Caſtle?
Oh none of both but are of high deſert:
My hand hath bin but idle, let it ſerue
To ranſome my two nephewes from their death,
Then haue I kept it to a worthy end.

speech.speaker: Moore.
speech.line: Nay come agree, whoſe hand ſhall gœ along
For feare they die before their pardon come.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: My hand ſhall gœ.

speech.speaker: Lu.
speech.line: By heauen it ſhall not gœ.

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: Sirs ſtriue no more, ſuch withered hearbs as theſe
Are meete for plucking vp, and therefore mine.

speech.speaker: Lu.
speech.line: Sweet Father, if I ſhall be thought thy ſonne,
Let me redeeme my brothers both from death.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: And for our fathers ſake, and mothers care,
Now let me ſhew a brothers loue to thee.

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: Agree betweene you, I will ſpare my hand.

speech.speaker: Lu.
speech.line: Then Ile gœ fetch an Axe.

speech.speaker: Mar
speech.line: But I will vſe the Axe.Exeunt

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: Come hither Aaron, Ile deceiue them both,
Lend me thy hand, and I will giue thee mine,

speech.speaker: Moore.
speech.line: If that be cal’d deceit, I will be honeſt,
And neuer whil’ſt I liue deceiue men ſo:
But Ile deceiue you in another ſort,
And that you’l ſay ere halfe an houre paſſe.

scene.stagedir: He cuts off Titus hand.
Enter Lucius and Marcus againe.

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: Now ſtay your ſtrife, what ſhall be, is diſpatcht:
Good Aron giue his Maieſtie my hand,
Tell him, it was a hand that warded him
From thouſand dangers: bid him bury it:
More hath it merited: That let it haue.
As for for my ſonnes, ſay I account of them,
As iewels purchaſt at an eaſie price,
And yet deere too, becauſe I bought mine owne.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: I gœ Andronicus, and for thy hand,
Looke by and by to haue thy ſonnes with thee:
Their heads I meane: Oh how this villany
Doth fat me with the very thoughts of it.
Let fooles dœ good, and faire men call for grace,
Aron will haue his ſoule blacke like his face.Exit.

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: O heere I liﬅ this one hand vp to heauen,
And bow this feeble ruine to the earth,
If any power pitties wretched teares,
To that I call: what wilt thou kneele with me?
Dœ then deare heart, for heauen ſhall heare our prayers,
Or with our ſighs weele breath the welkin dimme,
And ſtaine the Sun with fogge as ſomtime cloudes,
When they do hug him in their melting boſomes.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Oh brother ſpeake with poſſibilities,
And do not breake into theſe deepe extreames.

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: Is not my ſorrow deepe, hauing no bottome?
Then be my paſſions bottomleſſe with them.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: But yet let reaſon gouerne thy lament.

speech.speaker: Titus.
speech.line: If there were reaſon for theſe miſeries,
Then into limits could I binde my wœs:
When heauen doth weepe, doth not the earth oreﬂow?
If the windes rage, doth not the Sea wax mad,
Threatning the welkin with his big-ſwolne face?
And wilt thou haue a reaſon for this coile?
I am the Sea. Harke how her ſighes dœ ﬂow:
Shee is the weeping welkin, I the earth:
Then muſt my Sea be moued with her ſighes,
Then muſt my earth with her continuall teares,
Become a deluge: ouerﬂow’d and drown’d:
For why, my bowels cannot hide her wœs,
But like a drunkard muſt I vomit them:
Then giue me leaue, for looſers will haue leaue,
To eaſe their ſtomackes with their bitter tongues,

scene.stagedir: Enter a meſſenger with two heads and a hand.

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: Worthy Andronicus, ill art thou repaid,
For that good hand thou ſentſt the Emperour:
Heere are the heads of thy two noble ſonnes.
And heeres thy hand in ſcorne to thee ſent backe:
Thy griefes, their ſports: Thy reſolution mockt,
That wœ is me to thinke vpon thy wœs,
More then remembrance of my fathers death.Exit.

speech.speaker: Marc.
speech.line: Now let hot Ætna coole in Cicilie,
And be my heart an euer-burning hell:
Theſe miſeries are more then may be borne.
To weepe with them that weepe, doth eaſe ſome deale,
But ſorrow ﬂouted at, is double death.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: Ah that this ſight ſhould make ſo deep a wound,
And yet deteſted life not ſhrinke thereat:
That euer death ſhould let life beare his name,
Where life hath no more intereſt but to breath.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Alas poore hart that kiſſe is comfortleſſe,
As frozen water to a ſtarued ſnake.

speech.speaker: Titus.
speech.line: When will this fearefull ſlumber haue an end?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Now farwell ﬂatterie, die Andronicus,
Thou doſt not ſlumber, ſee thy two ſons heads,
Thy warlike hands, thy mangled daughter here:
Thy other baniſht ſonnes with this deere ſight
Strucke pale and bloodleſſe, and thy brother I,
Euen like a ſtony Image, cold and numme.
Ah now no more will I controule my griefes,
Rent off thy ſiluer haire, thy other hand
Gnawing with thy teeth, and be this diſmall ſight
The cloſing vp of our moſt wretched eyes:
Now is a time to ſtorme, why art thou ſtill?

speech.speaker: Titus.
speech.line: Ha, ha, ha,

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Why doſt thou laugh? it ﬁts not with this houre.

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: Why I haue not another teare to ſhed:
Beſides, this ſorrow is an enemy,
And would vſurpe vpon my watry eyes,
And make them blinde with tributarie teares.
Then which way ſhall I ﬁnde Reuenges Caue?
For theſe two heads dœ ſeeme to ſpeake to me,
And threat me, I ſhall neuer come to bliſſe,
Till all theſe miſchiefes be returned againe,
Euen in their throats that haue committed them.
Come let me ſee what taſke I haue to dœ,
You heauie people, circle me about,
That I may turne me to each one of you,
And ſweare vnto my ſoule to right your wrongs.
The vow is made, come Brother take a head,
And in this hand the other will I beare.
And Lauinia thou ſhalt be employd in theſe things:
Beare thou my hand ſweet wench betweene thy teeth:
As for thee boy, gœ get thee from my ſight,
Thou art an Exile, and thou muſt not ſtay,
Hie to the Gothes, and raiſe an army there,
And if you loue me, as I thinke you dœ,
Let’s kiſſe and part, for we haue much to dœ.Exeunt.

scene.stagedir: Manet Lucius.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: Farewell Andronicus my noble Father:
The woful’ſt man that euer liu’d in Rome:
Farewell proud Rome, til Lucius come againe,
He loues his pledges dearer then his life:
Farewell Lauinia my noble ſiſter,
O would thou wert as thou to fore haſt beene,
But now, nor Lucius nor Lauinia liues
But in obliuion and hateful griefes:
If Lucius liue, he will requit your wrongs,
And make proud Saturnine and his Empreſſe
Beg at the gates like Tarquin and his Queene.
Now will I to the Gothes and raiſe a power,
To be reueng’d on Rome and Saturnine.Exit Lucius

scene.stagedir: A Banket.
Enter Andronicus, Marcus, Lauinia, and the Boy.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: So, ſo, now ſit, and looke you eate no more
Then will preſerue iuſt ſo much ſtrength in vs
As will reuenge theſe bitter wœs of ours.
Marcus vnknit that ſorrow-wreathen knot:
Thy Neece and I (poore Creatures) want our hands
And cannot paſſionate our tenfold griefe,
With foulded Armes. This poore right hand of mine,
Is leﬅ to tirranize vppon my breaſt.
Who when my hart all mad with miſery,
Beats in this hollow priſon of my ﬂeſh,
Then thus I thumpe it downe.
Thou Map of wœ, that thus doſt talk in ſignes,
When thy poore hart beates without ragious beating,
Thou canſt not ſtrike it thus to make it ſtill?
Wound it with ſighing girle, kil it with grones:
Or get ſome little knife betweene thy teeth,
And iuſt againſt thy hart make thou a hole,
That all the teares that thy poore eyes let fall
May run into that ſinke, and ſoaking in,
Drowne the lamenting foole, in Sea ſalt teares.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Fy brother fy, teach her not thus to lay
Such violent hands vppon her tender life.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: How now! Has ſorrow made thee doate already?
Why Marcus, no man ſhould be mad but I:
What violent hands can ſhe lay on her life:
Ah, wherefore doſt thou vrge the name of hands,
To bid Æneas tell the tale twice ore
How Troy was burnt, and he made miſerable?
O handle not the theame, to talke of hands,
Leaſt we remember ſtill that we haue none,
Fie, ﬁe, how Frantiquely I ſquare my talke
As if we ſhould forget we had no hands:
If Marcus did not name the word of hands.
Come, lets fall too, and gentle girle eate this,
Heere is no drinke? Harke Marcus what ſhe ſaies,
I can interpret all her martir’d ſignes,
She ſaies, ſhe drinkes no other drinke but teares
Breu’d with her ſorrow: meſh’d vppon her cheekes,
Speechleſſe complayner, I will learne thy thought:
In thy dumb aƈtion, will I be as perfeƈt
As begging Hermits in their holy prayers.
Thou ſhalt not ſighe nor hold thy ſtumps to heauen,
Nor winke, nor nod, nor kneele, nor make a ſigne;
But I (of theſe) will wreſt an Alphabet,
And by ſtill praƈtice, learne to know thy meaning.

speech.speaker: Boy.
speech.line: Good grandſire leaue theſe bitter deepe laments,
Make my Aunt merry, with ſome pleaſing tale.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Alas, the tender boy in paſſion mou’d,
Doth weepe to ſee his grandſires heauineſſe.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: Peace tender Sapling, thou art made of teares,
And teares will quickly melt thy life away.
speech.stagedir: Marcus ſtrikes the diſh with a knife.
speech.line: What dœſt thou ſtrike at Marcus with knife.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: At that that I haue kil’d my Lord, a Flys

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: Out on the murderour: thou kil’ſt my hart,
Mine eyes cloi’d with view of Tirranie:
A deed of death done on the Innocent
Becoms not Titus brother: get thee gone,
I ſee thou art not for my company.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Alas (my Lord) I haue but kild a ﬂie.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: But? How: if that Flie had a father and mother?
How would he hang his ſlender gilded wings
And buz lamenting doings in the ayer,
Poore harmeleſſe Fly,
That with his pretty buzing melody,
Came heere to make vs merry,
And thou haſt kil’d him.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Pardon me ſir,
It was a blacke illfauour’d Fly,
Like to the Empreſſe Moore, therefore I kild him.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: O, o, o,
Then pardon me for reprehending thee,
For thou haſt done a Charitable deed:
Giue me thy knife, I will inſult on him,
Flattering my ſelfe, as if it were the Moore,
Come hither purpoſely to poyſon me.
There’s for thy ſelfe, and thats for Tamora: Ah ſirra,
Yet I thinke we are not brought ſo low,
But that betweene vs, we can kill a Fly,
That comes in likeneſſe of a Cole-blacke Moore.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Alas poore man, griefe ha’s ſo wrought on him,
He takes falſe ſhadowes, for true ſubſtances.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: Come, take away: Lauinia, gœ with me,
Ile to thy cloſſet, and gœ read with thee
Sad ſtories, chanced in the times of old.
Come boy, and gœ with me, thy ſight is young,
And thou ſhalt read, when mine begin to dazell.Exeunt

scene.stagedir: Enter young Lucius and Lauinia running aﬅer him, and the Boy ﬂies from her with his bookes vnder his arme. Enter Titus and Marcus

speech.speaker: Boy.
speech.line: Helpe Granſier helpe, my Aunt Lauinia,
Followes me euery where I know not why.
Good Vncle Marcus ſee how ſwiﬅ ſhe comes,
Alas ſweet Aunt, I know not what you meane.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Stand by me Lucius, dœ not feare thy Aunt.

speech.speaker: Titus.
speech.line: She loues thee boy too well to dœ thee harme

speech.speaker: Boy.
speech.line: I when my father was in Rome ſhe did.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: What meanes my Neece Lauinia by theſe ſignes?

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: Feare not Lucius, ſomewhat doth ſhe meane:
See Lucius ſee, how much ſhe makes of thee:
Some whether would ſhe haue thee gœ with her.
Ah boy, Cornelia neuer with more care
Read to her ſonnes, then ſhe hath read to thee,
Sweet Pœtry, and Tullies Oratour:
Canſt thou not geſſe wherefore ſhe plies thee thus?

speech.speaker: Boy.
speech.line: My Lord I know not I, nor can I geſſe,
Vnleſſe ſome ﬁt or frenzie do poſſeſſe her:
For I haue heard my Granſier ſay full oﬅ,
Extremitie of griefes would make men mad.
And I haue read that Hecuba of Troy,
Ran mad through ſorrow, that made me to feare,
Although my Lord, I know my noble Aunt,
Loues me as deare as ere my mother did,
And would not but in fury fright my youth,
Which made me downe to throw my bookes, and ﬂie
Cauſles perhaps, but pardon me ſweet Aunt,
And Madam, if my Vncle Marcus gœ,
I will moſt willingly attend your Ladyſhip.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Lucius I will.

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: How now Lauinia, Marcus what meanes this?
Some booke there is that ſhe deſires to ſee,
Which is it girle of theſe? Open them boy,
But thou art deeper read and better skild,
Come and take choyſe of all my Library,
And ſo beguile thy ſorrow, till the heauens
Reueale the damn’d contriuer of this deed.
What booke?
Why liﬅs ſhe vp her armes in ſequence thus?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: I thinke ſhe meanes that ther was more then one
Confederate in the faƈt, I more there was:
Or elſe to heauen ſhe heaues them to reuenge.

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: Lucius what booke is that ſhe toſſeth ſo?

speech.speaker: Boy.
speech.line: Grandſier ’tis Ouids Metamorphoſis,
My mother gaue it me.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: For loue of her that’s gone,
Perhaps ſhe culd it from among the reſt.

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: Soﬅ, ſo buſily ſhe turnes the leaues,
Helpe her, what would ſhe ﬁnde? Lauinia ſhall I read?
This is the tragicke tale of Philomel?
And treates of Tereus treaſon and his rape,
And rape I feare was roote of thine annoy.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: See brother ſee, note how ſhe quotes the leaues

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: Lauinia, wert thou thus ſurpriz’d ſweet girle,
Rauiſht and wrong’d as Philomela was?
Forc’d in the ruthleſſe, vaſt, and gloomy woods?
See, ſee, I ſuch a place there is where we did hunt,
(O had we neuer, neuer hunted there)
Patern’d by that the Pœt heere deſcribes,
By nature made for murthers and for rapes.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: O why ſhould nature build ſo foule a den,
Vnleſſe the Gods delight in tragedies?

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: Giue ſignes ſweet girle, for heere are none but friends
What Romaine Lord it was durſt do the deed?
Or ſlunke not Saturnine, as Tarquin erſt,
That leﬅ the Campe to ſinne in Lucrece bed.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Sit downe ſweet Neece, brother ſit downe by me,
Appollo, Pallas, Ioue, or Mercury,
Inſpire me that I may this treaſon ﬁnde.
My Lord looke heere, looke heere Lauinia.

scene.stagedir: He writes his Name with his ſtaffe, and guides it with feete and mouth
scene.line: This ſandie plot is plaine, guide if thou canſt
This aﬅer me, I haue writ my name,
Without the helpe of any hand at all.
Curſt be that hart that forc’ſt vs to that ſhiﬅ:
Write thou good Neece, and heere diſplay at laſt,
What God will haue diſcouered for reuenge,
Heauen guide thy pen to print thy ſorrowes plaine,
That we may know the Traytors and the truth.
scene.stagedir: She takes the ſtaffe in her mouth, and guides it with her ſtumps and writes

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: Oh dœ ye read my Lord what ſhe hath writs?
Stuprum, Chiron, Demetrius.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: What, what, the luſtfull ſonnes of Tamora,
Performers of this hainous bloody deed?

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: Magni Dominator poli,

line.italic: Tam lentus audis ſcelera, tam lentus vides?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Oh calme thee gentle Lord: Although I know
There is enough written vpon this earth,
To ſtirre a mutinie in the mildeſt thoughts,
And arme the mindes of infants to exclaimes.
My Lord kneele downe with me: Lauinia kneele,
And kneele ſweet boy, the Romaine Heƈtors hope,
And ſweare with me, as with the wofull Feere
And father of that chaſt diſhonoured Dame,
Lord Iunius Brutus ſweare for Lucrece rape,
That we will proſecute (by good aduiſe)
Mortall reuenge vpon theſe traytorous Gothes,
And ſee their blood, or die with this reproach.

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: Tis ſure enough, and you knew how.
But if you hunt theſe Beare-whelpes, then beware
The Dam will wake, and if ſhe winde you once,
Shee’s with the Lyon deepely ſtill in league.
And lulls him whilſt ſhe playeth on her backe,
And when he ſleepes will ſhe do what ſhe liſt.
You are a young huntſman Marcus, let it alone:
And come, I will goe get a leafe of braſſe,
And with a Gad of ſteele will write theſe words,
And lay it by: the angry Northerne winde
Will blow theſe ſands like Sibels leaues abroad,
And wheres your leſſon then. Boy what ſay you?

speech.speaker: Boy.
speech.line: I ſay my Lord, that if I were a man,
Their mothers bed-chamber ſhould not be ſafe,
For theſe bad bond-men to the yoake of Rome.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: I that’s my boy, thy father hath full oﬅ,
For his vngratefull country done the like.

speech.speaker: Boy.
