speech.line: And Vncle ſo will I, and if I liue.

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: Come gœ with me into mine Armorie,
Lucius Ile ﬁt thee, and withall, my boy
Shall carry from me to the Empreſſe ſonnes,
Preſents that I intend to ſend them both,
Come, come, thou’lt do thy meſſage, wilt thou not?

speech.speaker: Boy.
speech.line: I with my dagger in their boſomes Grandſire:

speech.speaker: Ti.
speech.line: No boy not ſo, Ile teach thee another courſe,
Lauinia come, Marcus looke to my houſe,
Lucius and Ile gœ braue it at the Court,
I marry will we ſir, and weele be waited on.Exeunt.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: O heauens! Can you heare a good man grone
And not relent, or not compaſſion him?
Marcus attend him in his extaſie,
That hath more ſcars of ſorrow in his heart,
Then fœ-mens markes vpon his batter’d ſhield,
But yet ſo iuſt, that he will not reuenge,
Reuenge the heauens for old Andronicus.Exit

scene.stagedir: Enter Aron, Chiron and Demetrius at one dore: and at another dore young Lucius and another, with a bundle of weapons, and verſes writ vpon them

speech.speaker: Chi.
speech.line: Demetrius heeres the ſonne of Lucius,
He hath ſome meſſage to deliuer vs.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: I ſome mad meſſage from his mad Grandfather.

speech.speaker: Boy.
speech.line: My Lords, with all the humbleneſſe I may,
I greete your honours from Andronicus,
And pray the Romane Gods confound you both.

speech.speaker: Deme.
speech.line: Gramercie louely Lucius, what’s the newes?
For villanie’s markt with rape. May it pleaſe you,
My Grandſire well aduiſ’d hath ſent by me,
The goodlieſt weapons of his Armorie,
To gratiﬁe your honourable youth,
The hope of Rome, for ſo he bad me ſay:
And ſo I do and with his giﬅs preſent
Your Lordſhips, when euer you haue need,
You may be armed and appointed well,
And ſo I leaue you both: like bloody villaines.Exit

speech.speaker: Deme.
speech.line: What’s heere? a ſcrole, & written round about?
Let’s ſee.
Integer vitae ſceleriſque purus, non egit maury iaculis nec arcus.

speech.speaker: Chi.
speech.line: O ’tis a verſe in Horace, I know it well.
I read it in the Grammer long agœ.

speech.speaker: Moore.
speech.line: I iuſt, a verſe in Horace: right, you haue it,
Now what a thing it is to be an Aſſe?
Heer’s no ſound ieſt, the old man hath found their guilt,
And ſends the weapons wrapt about with lines,
That wound (beyond their feeling) to the quick:
But were our witty Empreſſe well a foot,
She would applaud Andronicus conceit:
But let her reſt, in her vnreſt a while.
And now young Lords, wa’s tnot a happy ſtarre
Led vs to Rome ſtrangers, and more then ſo;
Captiues, to be aduanced to this height?
It did me good before the Pallace gate,
To braue the Tribune in his brothers hearing.

speech.speaker: Deme.
speech.line: But me more good, to ſee ſo great a Lord
Baſely inſinuate, and ſend vs giﬅs.

speech.speaker: Moore.
speech.line: Had he not reaſon Lord Demetrius?
Did you not vſe his daughter very friendly?

speech.speaker: Deme.
speech.line: I would we had a thouſand Romane Dames
At ſuch a bay, by turne to ſerue our luſt.

speech.speaker: Chi.
speech.line: A charitable wiſh, and full of loue.

speech.speaker: Moore.
speech.line: Heere lack’s but your mother for to ſay, Amen.

speech.speaker: Chi.
speech.line: And that would ſhe for twenty thouſand more.

speech.speaker: Deme.
speech.line: Come, let vs go, and pray to all the Gods
For our beloued mother in her paines.

speech.speaker: Moore.
speech.line: Pray to the deuils, the gods haue giuen vs ouer.

scene.stagedir: Flouriſh.

speech.speaker: Dem.
speech.line: Why do the Emperors trumpets ﬂouriſh thus?

speech.speaker: Chi.
speech.line: Belike for ioy the Emperour hath a ſonne.

speech.speaker: Deme.
speech.line: Soﬅ, who comes heere?

scene.stagedir: Enter Nurſe with a blacke a Moore childe.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: Good morrow Lords:
O tell me, did you ſee Aaron the Moore?

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: Well, more or leſſe, or nere a whit at all,
Heere Aaron is, and what with Aaron now?

speech.speaker: Nurſe.
speech.line: Oh gentle Aaron, we are all vndone.
Now helpe, or wœ betide thee euermore.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: Why, what a catterwalling doſt thou keepe?
What doſt thou wrap and fumble in thine armes?

speech.speaker: Nurſe.
speech.line: O that which I would hide from heauens eye,
Our Empreſſe ſhame, and ſtately Romes diſgrace,
She is deliuered Lords, ſhe is deliuered.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: To whom?

speech.speaker: Nurſe.
speech.line: I meane ſhe is brought a bed?

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: Wel God giue her good reſt,
What hath he ſent her?

speech.speaker: Nurſe.
speech.line: A deuill.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: Why then ſhe is the Deuils Dam: a ioyfull iſſue.

speech.speaker: Nurſe.
speech.line: A ioyleſſe, diſmall, blacke &, ſorrowfull iſſue,
Heere is the babe as loathſome as a toad,
Among’ſt the faireſt breeders of our clime,
The Empreſſe ſends it thee, thy ſtampe, thy ſeale,
And bids thee chriſten it with thy daggers point.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: Out you whore, is black ſo baſe a hue?
Sweet blowſe, you are a beautious bloſſome ſure.

speech.speaker: Deme.
speech.line: Villaine what haſt thou done?

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: That which thou canſt not vndœ.

speech.speaker: Chi.
speech.line: Thou haſt vndone our mother.

speech.speaker: Deme.
speech.line: And therein helliſh dog, thou haſt vndone,
Wœ to her chance, and damn’d her loathed choyce,
Accur’ſt the off-ſpring of ſo foule a ﬁend.

speech.speaker: Chi.
speech.line: It ſhall not liue.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: It ſhall not die.

speech.speaker: Nurse.
speech.line: Aaron it muſt, the mother wils it ſo.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: What, muſt it Nurſe? Then let no man but I
Dœ execution on my ﬂeſh and blood.

speech.speaker: Deme.
speech.line: Ile broach the Tadpole on my Rapiers point:
Nurſe giue it me, my ſword ſhall ſoone diſpatch it.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: Sooner this ſword ſhall plough thy bowels vp.
Stay murtherous villaines, will you kill your brother?
Now by the burning Tapers of the skie,
That ſ’hone ſo brightly when this Boy was got,
He dies vpon my Semitars ſharpe point,
That touches this my ﬁrſt borne ſonne and heire.
I tell you young-lings, not Enceladus
With all his threatning band of Typhons broode,
Nor great Alcides, nor the God of warre,
Shall ceaze this prey out of his fathers hands:
What, what, ye ſanguine ſhallow harted Boyes,
Ye white-limb’d walls, ye Ale-houſe painted ſignes,
Cole-blacke is better then another hue,
In that it ſcornes to beare another hue:
For all the water in the Ocean,
Can neuer turne the Swans blacke legs to white,
Although ſhe laue them hourely in the ﬂood:
Tell the Empreſſe from me, I am of age
To keepe mine owne, excuſe it how ſhe can

speech.speaker: Deme.
speech.line: Wilt thou betray thy noble miſtris thus?

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: My miſtris is my miſtris: this my ſelfe,
The vigour, and the piƈture of my youth:
This, before all the world do I preferre,
This mauger all the world will I keepe ſafe,
Or ſome of you ſhall ſmoake for it in Rome.

speech.speaker: Deme.
speech.line: By this our mother is for euer ſham’d.

speech.speaker: Chi.
speech.line: Rome will deſpiſe her for this foule eſcape.

speech.speaker: Nur.
speech.line: The Emperour in his rage will doome her death.

speech.speaker: Chi.
speech.line: I bluſh to thinke vpon this ignominie.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: Why ther’s the priuiledge your beauty beares:
Fie trecherous hue, that will betray with bluſhing
The cloſe enaƈts and counſels of the hart:
Heer’s a young Lad fram’d of another leere,
Looke how the blacke ſlaue ſmiles vpon the father;
As who ſhould ſay, old Lad I am thine owne.
He is your brother Lords, ſenſibly fed
Of that ſelfe blood that ﬁrſt gaue life to you,
And from that wombe where you impriſoned were
He is infranchiſed and come to light:
Nay he is your brother by the ſurer ſide,
Although my ſeale be ſtamped in his face.

speech.speaker: Nurſe.
speech.line: Aaron what ſhall I ſay vnto the Empreſſe?

speech.speaker: Dem.
speech.line: Aduiſe thee Aaron, what is to be done,
And we will all ſubſcribe to thy aduiſe:
Saue thou the child, ſo we may all be ſafe.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: Then ſit we downe and let vs all conſult.
My ſonne and I will haue the winde of you:
Keepe there, now talke at pleaſure of your ſafety.

speech.speaker: Deme.
speech.line: How many women ſaw this childe of his?

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: Why ſo braue Lords, when we ioyne in league
I am a Lambe: but if you braue the Moore,
The chafed Bore, the mountaine Lyoneſſe,
The Ocean ſwells not ſo as Aaron ſtormes:
But ſay againe, how many ſaw the childe?

speech.speaker: Nurſe.
speech.line: Cornelia, the midwife, and my ſelfe,
And none elſe but the deliuered Empreſſe.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: The Empreſſe, the Midwife, and your ſelfe,
Two may keepe counſell, when the third’s away:
Gœ to the Empreſſe, tell her this I ſaid,He kils her
Weeke, weeke, ſo cries a Pigge prepared to th’ ſpit.

speech.speaker: Deme.
speech.line: What mean’ſt thou Aaron?
Wherefore did’ſt thou this?

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: O Lord ſir, ’tis a deed of pollicie?
Shall ſhe liue to betray this guilt of our’s:
A long tongu’d babling Goſſip? No Lords no:
And now be it knowne to you my full intent.
Not farre, one Muliteus my Country-man
His wife but yeſternight was brought to bed,
His childe is like to her, faire as you are:
Gœ packe with them, and giue the mother gold,
And tell them both the circumſtance of all,
And how by this their Childe ſhall be aduaunc’d,
And be receiued for the Emperours heyre,
And ſubſtituted in the place of mine,
To calme this tempeſt whirling in the Court,
And let the Emperour dandle him for his owne,
Harke ye Lords, ye ſee I haue giuen her phyſicke,
And you muſt needs beſtow her funerall,
The ﬁelds are neere, and you are gallant Groomes:
This done, ſee that you take no longer daies
But ſend the Midwife preſently to me.
The Midwife and the Nurſe well made away,
Then let the Ladies tattle what they pleaſe.

speech.speaker: Chi.
speech.line: Aaron I ſee thou wilt not truſt the ayre with ſecrets.

speech.speaker: Deme.
speech.line: For this care of Tamora,
Her ſelfe, and hers are highly bound to thee.Exeunt.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: Now to the Gothes, as ſwiﬅ as Swallow ﬂies,
There to diſpoſe this treaſure in mine armes,
And ſecretly to greete the Empreſſe friends:
Come on you thick-lipt-ſlaue, Ile beare you hence,
For it is you that puts vs to our ſhiﬅs:
Ile make you feed on berries, and on rootes,
And feed on curds and whay, and ſucke the Goate,
And cabbin in a Caue, and bring you vp
To be a warriour, and command a Campe.Exit

scene.stagedir: Enter Titus, old Marcus, young Lucius, and other gentlemen with bowes, and Titus beares the arrowes with Letters on the end of them.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Come Marcus, come, kinſmen this is the way.
Sir Boy let me ſee your Archerie,
Looke yee draw home enough, and ’tis there ſtraight:
Terras Aſtrea reliquit, be you remembred Marcus.
She’s gone, ſhe’s ﬂed, ſirs take you to your tooles,
You Coſens ſhall gœ ſound the Ocean:
And caſt your nets, haply you may ﬁnd her in the Sea,
Yet ther’s as little iuſtice as at Land:
No Publius and Sempronius, you muſt dœ it,
’Tis you muſt dig with Mattocke, and with Spade,
And pierce the inmoſt Center of the earth:
Then when you come to Plutœs Region,
I pray you deliuer him this petition,
Tell him it is for iuſtice, and for aide,
And that it comes from old Andronicus,
Shaken with ſorrowes in vngratefull Rome.
Ah Rome! Well, well, I made thee miſerable,
What time I threw the peoples ſuffrages
On him that thus doth tyrannize ore me.
Gœ get you gone, and pray be carefull all,
And leaue you not a man of warre vnſearcht,
This wicked Emperour may haue ſhipt her hence,
And kinſmen then we may gœ pipe for iuſtice.

speech.speaker: Marc.
speech.line: O Publius is not this a heauie caſe
To ſee thy Noble Vnckle thus diſtraƈt?

speech.speaker: Publ.
speech.line: Therefore my Lords it highly vs concernes,
By day and night t’attend him carefully:
And feede his humour kindely as we may,
Till time beget ſome carefull remedie.

speech.speaker: Marc.
speech.line: Kinſmen, his ſorrowes are paſt remedie.
Ioyne with the Gothes, and with reuengefull warre,
Take wreake on Rome for this ingratitude,
And vengeance on the Traytor Saturnine.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Publius how now? how now my Maiſters?
What haue you met with her?

speech.speaker: Publ.
speech.line: No my good Lord, but Pluto ſends you word,
If you will haue reuenge from hell you ſhall,
Marrie for iuſtice ſhe is ſo imploy’d,
He thinkes with Ioue in heauen, or ſome where elſe:
So that perforce you muſt needs ſtay a time.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: He doth me wrong to feed me with delayes,
Ile diue into the burning Lake below,
And pull her out of Acaron by the heeles.
Marcus we are but ſhrubs, no Cedars we,
No big-bon’d-men, fram’d of the Cyclops ſize,
But mettall Marcus ſteele to the very backe,
Yet wrung with wrongs more then our backe can beare:
And ſith there’s no iuſtice in earth nor hell,
We will ſollicite heauen, and moue the Gods
To ſend downe Iuſtice for to wreake’ our wongs:
Come to this geare, you are a good Archer Marcus.
Ad Iouem, that’s for you: here ad Appollonem,
Ad Martem, that’s for my ſelfe,
Heere Boy to Pallas, heere to Mercury,
To Saturnine, to Caius, not to Saturnine,
You were as good to ſhoote againſt the winde.
Too it Boy, Marcus looſe when I bid:
Of my word, I haue written to effeƈt,
Ther’s not a God leﬅ vnſollicited.

speech.speaker: Marc.
speech.line: Kinſmen, ſhoot all your ſhaﬅs into the Court,
We will afﬂiƈt the Emperour in his pride.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Now Maiſters draw, Oh well ſaid Lucius:
Good Boy in Virgœs lap, giue it Pallas.

speech.speaker: Marc.
speech.line: My Lord, I aime a Mile beyond the Moone,
Your letter is with Iupiter by this.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Ha, ha, Publius, Publius, what haſt thou done?
See, ſee, thou haſt ſhot off one of Taurus hornes.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: This was the ſport my Lord, when Publius ſhot,
The Bull being gal’d, gaue Aries ſuch a knocke,
That downe fell both the Rams hornes in the Court,
And who ſhould ﬁnde them but the Empreſſe villaine:
She laught, and told the Moore he ſhould not chooſe
But giue them to his Maiſter for a preſent.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Why there it gœs, God giue your Lordſhip ioy.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Clowne with a baſket and two Pigeons in it.

speech.speaker: Titus.
speech.line: Newes, newes, from heauen,
Marcus the poaſt is come.
Sirrah, what tydings? haue you any letters?
Shall I haue Iuſtice, what ſayes Iupiter?

speech.speaker: Clowne.
speech.line: Ho the Iibbetmaker, he ſayes that he hath ta-
ken them downe againe, for the man muſt not be hang’d
till the next weeke.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: But what ſayes Iupiter I aske thee?

speech.speaker: Clowne.
speech.line: Alas ſir I know not Iupiter:
I neuer dranke with him in all my life.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Why villaine art not thou the Carrier?

speech.speaker: Clowne.
speech.line: I of my Pigions ſir, nothing elſe.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Why, did’ſt thou not come from heauen?

speech.speaker: Clowne.
speech.line: From heauen? Alas ſir, I neuer came there,
God forbid I ſhould be ſo bold, to preſſe to heauen in my
young dayes. Why I am going with my pigeons to the
Tribunall Plebs, to take vp a matter of brawle, betwixt
my Vncle, and one of the Emperialls men.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Why ſir, that is as ﬁt as can be to ſerue for your
Oration, and let him deliuer the Pigions to the Emperour
from you.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Tell mee, can you deliuer an Oration to the Em-
perour with a Grace?

speech.speaker: Clowne.
speech.line: Nay truely ſir, I could neuer ſay grace in all
my life.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Sirrah come hither, make no more adœ,
But giue your Pigeons to the Emperour,
By me thou ſhalt haue Iuſtice at his hands.
Hold, hold, meane while her’s money for thy charges.
Giue me pen and inke.
Sirrah, can you with a Grace deliuer a Supplication?

speech.speaker: Clowne.
speech.line: I ſir

speech.speaker: Titus.
speech.line: Then here is a Supplication for you, and when
you come to him, at the ﬁrſt approach you muſt kneele,
then kiſſe his foote, then deliuer vp your Pigeons, and
then looke for your reward. Ile be at hand ſir, ſee you do
it brauely.

speech.speaker: Clowne.
speech.line: I warrant you ſir, let me alone.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Sirrha haſt thou a knife? Come let me ſee it.
Heere Marcus, fold it in the Oration,
For thou haſt made it like an humble Suppliant:
And when thou haſt giuen it the Emperour,
Knocke at my dore, and tell me what he ſayes.

speech.speaker: Clowne
speech.line: God be with you ſir, I will.Exit.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Come Marcus let vs gœ, Publius follow me.

scene.stagedir: Exeunt.
Enter Emperour and Empreſſe, and her two ſonnes, the Emperour brings the Arrowes in his hand that Titus ſhot at him

speech.speaker: Satur.
speech.line: Why Lords,
What wrongs are theſe? was euer ſeene
An Emperour in Rome thus ouerborne,
Troubled, Confronted thus, and for the extent
Of egall iuſtice, vſ’d in ſuch contempt?
My Lords, you know the mightfull Gods,
(How euer theſe diſturbers of our peace
Buz in the peoples eares) there nought hath paſt,
But euen with law againſt the willfull Sonnes
Of old Andronicus. And what and if
His ſorrowes haue ſo ouerwhelm’d his wits,
Shall we be thus afﬂiƈted in his wreakes,
His ﬁts, his frenzie, and his bitterneſſe?
And now he writes to heauen for his redreſſe.
See, heeres to Ioue, and this to Mercury,
This to Apollo, this to the God of warre:
Sweet ſcrowles to ﬂie about the ſtreets of Rome:
What’s this but Libelling againſt the Senate,
And blazoning our Iniuſtice euery where?
A goodly humour, is it not my Lords?
As who would ſay, in Rome no Iuſtice were.
But if I liue, his fained extaſies
Shall be no ſhelter to theſe outrages:
But he and his ſhall know, that Iuſtice liues
In Saturninus health; whom if he ſleepe,
Hee’l ſo awake, as he in fury ſhall
Cut off the proud’ſt Conſpirator that liues.

speech.speaker: Tamo.
speech.line: My gracious Lord, my louely Saturnine,
Lord of my life, Commander of my thoughts,
Calme thee, and beare the faults of Titus age,
Th’ effeƈts of ſorrow for his valiant Sonnes,
Whoſe loſſe hath pier’ſt him deepe, and ſcar’d his heart;
And rather comfort his diſtreſſed plight,
Then proſecute the meaneſt or the beſt
For theſe contempts. Why thus it ſhall become
High witted Tamora to gloſe with all:Aſide.
But Titus, I haue touch’d thee to the quicke,
Thy life blood out: If Aaron now be wiſe,
Then is all ſafe, the Anchor’s in the Port.
How now good fellow, would’ſt thou ſpeake with vs?

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: Yea forſooth, and your Miſterſhip be Emperiall.

speech.speaker: Tam.
speech.line: Empreſſe I am, but yonder ſits the Emperour.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: ’Tis he; God & Saint Stephen giue you good den;
I haue brought you a Letter, & a couple of Pigions heere.

scene.stagedir: He reads the Letter.

speech.speaker: Satu.
speech.line: Gœ take him away, and hang him preſently.

speech.speaker: Clowne.
speech.line: How much money muſt I haue?

speech.speaker: Tam.
speech.line: Come ſirrah you muſt be hang’d.

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: Hang’d? ber Lady, then I haue brought vp a neck
to a faire end.Exit.

speech.speaker: Satu.
speech.line: Deſpightfull and intollerable wrongs,
Shall I endure this monſtrous villany?
I know from whence this ſame deuiſe proceedes:
May this be borne? As if his traytrous Sonnes,
That dy’d by law for murther of our Brother,
Haue by my meanes beene butcher’d wrongfully?
Gœ dragge the villaine hither by the haire,
Nor Age, nor Honour, ſhall ſhape priuiledge:
For this proud mocke, Ile be thy ſlaughter man:
Sly franticke wretch, that holp’ſt to make me great,
In hope thy ſelfe ſhould gouerne Rome and me.

scene.stagedir: Enter Nuntius Emillius.

speech.speaker: Satur.
speech.line: What newes with thee Emillius?

speech.speaker: Emil.
speech.line: Arme my Lords, Rome neuer had more cauſe,
The Gothes haue gather’d head, and with a power
Of high reſolued men, bent to the ſpoyle
They hither march amaine, vnder conduƈt
Of Lucius, Sonne to old Andronicus:
Who threats in courſe of this reuenge to do
As much as euer Coriolanus did.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Is warlike Lucius Generall of the Gothes?
Theſe tydings nip me, and I hang the head
As ﬂowers with froſt, or graſſe beat downe with ſtormes:
I, now begins our ſorrowes to approach,
’Tis he the common people loue ſo much,
My ſelfe hath oﬅen heard them ſay,
(When I haue walked like a priuate man)
That Lucius baniſhment was wrongfully,
And they haue wiſht that Lucius were their Emperour.

speech.speaker: Tam.
speech.line: Why ſhould you feare? Is not our City ſtrong?

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: I, but the Cittizens fauour Lucius,
And will reuolt from me, to ſuccour him.

speech.speaker: Tam.
speech.line: King, be thy thoughts Imperious like thy name.
Is the Sunne dim’d, that Gnats do ﬂie in it?
The Eagle ſuffers little Birds to ſing,
And is not carefull what they meane thereby,
Knowing that with the ſhadow of his wings,
He can at pleaſure ſtint their melodie.
Euen ſo mayeſt thou, the giddy men of Rome,
Then cheare thy ſpirit, for know thou Emperour,
I will enchaunt the old Andronicus,
With words more ſweet, and yet more dangerous
Then baites to ﬁſh, or hony ſtalkes to ſheepe,
When as the one is wounded with the baite,
The other rotted with delicious foode.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: But he will not entreat his Sonne for vs.

speech.speaker: Tam.
speech.line: If Tamora entreat him, then he will,
For I can ſmooth and ﬁll his aged eare,
With golden promiſes, that were his heart
Almoſt Impregnable, his old eares deafe,
Yet ſhould both eare and heart, obey my tongue.
Gœ thou before to our Embaſſadour,
Say, that the Emperour requeſts a parly
Of warlike Lucius, and appoint the meeting.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Emillius do this meſſage Honourably,
And if he ſtand in Hoſtage for his ſafety,
Bid him demaund what pledge will pleaſe him beſt.

speech.speaker: Emill
speech.line: Your bidding ſhall I do effeƈtually.Exit.

speech.speaker: Tam.
speech.line: Now will I to that old Andronicus,
And temper him with all the Art I haue,
To plucke proud Lucius from the warlike Gothes.
And now ſweet Emperour be blithe againe,
And bury all thy feare in my deuiſes.

speech.speaker: Satu
speech.line: Then gœ ſucceſſantly and plead for him.Exit.

scene.stagedir: Flouriſh. Enter Lucius with an Army of Gothes, with Drum and Souldiers

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: Approued warriours, and my faithfull Friends,
I haue receiued Letters from great Rome,
Which ſigniﬁes what hate they beare their Emperour,
And how deſirous of our ſight they are.
Therefore great Lords, be as your Titles witneſſe,
Imperious and impatient of your wrongs,
And wherein Rome hath done you any ſcathe,
Let him make treble ſatiſfaƈtion.

speech.speaker: Goth.
speech.line: Braue ſlip, ſprung from the Great Andronicus,
Whoſe name was once our terrour, now our comfort,
Whoſe high exploits, and honourable Deeds,
Ingratefull Rome requites with foule contempt:
Behold in vs, weele follow where thou lead’ſt,
Like ſtinging Bees in hotteſt Sommers day,
Led by their Maiſter to the ﬂowred ﬁelds,
And be aueng’d on curſed Tamora:
And as he ſaith, ſo ſay we all with him.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: I humbly thanke him, and I thanke you all.
But who comes heere, led by a luſty Goth?

scene.stagedir: Enter a Goth leading of Aaron with his child in his armes

speech.speaker: Goth.
speech.line: Renowned Lucius, from our troups I ſtraid,
To gaze vpon a ruinous Monaſterie,
And as I earneſtly did ﬁxe mine eye
Vpon the waſted building, ſuddainely
I heard a childe cry vnderneath a wall:
I made vnto the noyſe, when ſoone I heard,
The crying babe control’d with this diſcourſe:
Peace Tawny ſlaue, halfe me, and halfe thy Dam,
Did not thy Hue bewray whoſe brat thou art?
Had nature lent thee, but thy Mothers looke,
Villaine thou might’ſt haue bene an Emperour.
But where the Bull and Cow are both milk-white,
They neuer do beget a cole-blacke-Calfe:
Peace, villaine peace, euen thus he rates the babe,
For I muſt beare thee to a truſty Goth,
Who when he knowes thou art the Empreſſe babe,
Will hold thee dearely for thy Mothers ſake.
With this, my weapon drawne I ruſht vpon him,
Surpriz’d him ſuddainely, and brought him hither
To vſe, as you thinke needefull of the man.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: Oh worthy Goth, this is the incarnate deuill,
That rob’d Andronicus of his good hand:
This is the Pearle that pleaſ’d your Empreſſe eye,
And heere’s the Baſe Fruit of his burning luſt.
Say wall-ey’d ſlaue, whether would’ſt thou conuay
This growing Image of thy ﬁend-like face?
Why doſt not ſpeake? what deafe? Not a word?
A halter Souldiers, hang him on this Tree,
And by his ſide his Fruite of Baſtardie.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: Touch not the Boy, he is of Royall blood.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: Too like the Syre for euer being good.
Firſt hang the Child that he may ſee it ſprall,
A ſight to vexe the Fathers ſoule withall.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: Get me a Ladder Lucius, ſaue the Childe,
And beare it from me to the Empreſſe:
If thou do this, Ile ſhew thee wondrous things,
That highly may aduantage thee to heare;
If thou wilt not, befall what may befall,
Ile ſpeake no more: but vengeance rot you all.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: Say on, and if it pleaſe me which thou ſpeak’ſt,
Thy child ſhall liue, and I will ſee it Nouriſht.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: And if it pleaſe thee? why aſſure thee Lucius,
’Twill vexe thy ſoule to heare what I ſhall ſpeake:
For I muſt talke of Murthers, Rapes, and Maſſacres,
Aƈts of Blacke-night, abhominable Deeds,
Complots of Miſchiefe, Treaſon, Villanies
Ruthfull to heare, yet pittiouſly perform’d,
And this ſhall all be buried by my death,
Vnleſſe thou ſweare to me my Childe ſhall liue.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: Tell on thy minde,
I ſay thy Childe ſhall liue.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: Sweare that he ſhall, and then I will begin.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: Who ſhould I ſweare by,
Thou beleeueſt no God,
That graunted, how can’ſt thou beleeue an oath?

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: What if I do not, as indeed I do not,
Yet for I know thou art Religious,
And haſt a thing within thee, called Conſcience,
With twenty Popiſh trickes and Ceremonies,
Which I haue ſeene thee carefull to obſerue:
Therefore I vrge thy oath, for that I know
An Ideot holds his Bauble for a God,
And keepes the oath which by that God he ſweares,
To that Ile vrge him: therefore thou ſhalt vow
By that ſame God, what God ſo ere it be
That thou adoreſt, and haſt in reuerence,
To ſaue my Boy, to nouriſh and bring him vp,
Ore elſe I will diſcouer nought to thee.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: Euen by my God I ſweare to to thee I will.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: Firſt know thou,
I begot him on the Empreſſe.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: Oh moſt Inſatiate luxurious woman!

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: Tut Lucius, this was but a deed of Charitie,
To that which thou ſhalt heare of me anon,
’Twas her two Sonnes that murdered Baſſianus,
They cut thy Siſters tongue, and rauiſht her,
And cut her hands off, and trim’d her as thou ſaw’ſt.

speech.speaker: Lucius.
speech.line: Oh deteſtable villaine!
Call’ſt thou that Trimming?

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: Why ſhe was waſht, and cut, and trim’d,
And ’twas trim ſport for them that had the doing of it.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: Oh barbarous beaſtly villaines like thy ſelfe!

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: Indeede, I was their Tutor to inſtruƈt them
That Codding ſpirit had they from their Mother,
As ſure a Card as euer wonne the Set:
That bloody minde I thinke they learn’d of me,
As true a Dog as euer fought at head.
Well, let my Deeds be witneſſe of my worth:
I trayn’d thy Bretheren to that guilefull Hole,
Where the dead Corps of Baſſianus lay:
I wrote the Letter, that thy Father found,
And hid the Gold within the Letter mention’d.
Confederate with the Queene, and her two Sonnes,
And what not done, that thou haſt cauſe to rue,
Wherein I had no ſtroke of Miſcheife in it.
I play’d the Cheater for thy Fathers hand,
And when I had it, drew my ſelfe apart,
And almoſt broke my heart with extreame laughter.
I pried me through the Creuice of a Wall,
When for his hand, he had his two Sonnes heads,
Beheld his teares, and laught ſo hartily,
That both mine eyes were rainie like to his:
And when I told the Empreſſe of this ſport,
She ſounded almoſt at my pleaſing tale,
And for my tydings, gaue me twenty kiſſes.

speech.speaker: Goth.
speech.line: What canſt thou ſay all this, and neuer bluſh?

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: I, like a blacke Dogge, as the ſaying is.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: Art thou not ſorry for theſe hainous deedes?

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: I, that I had not done a thouſand more:
Euen now I curſe the day, and yet I thinke
Few come within few compaſſe of my curſe,
Wherein I did not ſome Notorious ill,
As kill a man, or elſe deuiſe his death,
Rauiſh a Maid, or plot the way to do it,
Accuſe ſome Innocent, and forſweare my ſelfe,
Set deadly Enmity betweene two Friends,
Make poore mens Cattell breake their neckes,
Set ﬁre on Barnes and Hayſtackes in the night,
And bid the Owners quench them with the teares:
Oﬅ haue I dig’d vp dead men from their graues,
And ſet them vpright at their deere Friends doore,
Euen when their ſorrowes almoſt was forgot,
And on their ſkinnes, as on the Barke of Trees,
Haue with my knife carued in Romaine Letters,
Let not your ſorrow die, though I am dead.
Tut, I haue done a thouſand dreadfull things
As willingly, as one would kill a Fly,
And nothing greeues me hartily indeede,
But that I cannot dœ ten thouſand more.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: Bring downe the diuell, for he muſt not die
So ſweet a death as hanging preſently.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: If there be diuels, would I were a deuill,
To liue and burne in euerlaſting ﬁre,
So I might haue your company in hell,
But to torment you with my bitter tongue.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: Sirs ſtop his mouth, & let him ſpeake no more.

scene.stagedir: Enter Emillius.

speech.speaker: Goth.
speech.line: My Lord, there is a Meſſenger from Rome
Deſires to be admitted to your preſence.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Let him come neere.
Welcome Emillius, what the newes from Rome?

speech.speaker: Emi.
speech.line: Lord Lucius, and you Princes of the Gothes,
The Romaine Emperour greetes you all by me,
And for he vnderſtands you are in Armes,
He craues a parly at your Fathers houſe
Willing you to demand your Hoſtages,
And they ſhall be immediately deliuered.

speech.speaker: Goth.
speech.line: What ſaies our Generall?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Emillius, let the Emperour giue his pledges
Vnto my Father, and my Vncle Marcus,Flouriſh.
And we will come: march away.Exeunt.

scene.stagedir: Enter Tamora, and her two Sonnes diſguiſed.

speech.speaker: Tam.
speech.line: Thus in this ſtrange and ſad Habilliament,
I will encounter with Andronicus,
And ſay, I am Reuenge ſent from below,
To ioyne with him and right his hainous wrongs:
Knocke at his ſtudy where they ſay he keepes,
To ruminate ſtrange plots of dire Reuenge,
Tell him Reuenge is come to ioyne with him,
And worke confuſion on his Enemies.

scene.stagedir: They knocke and Titus opens his ſtudy dore.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Who doth molleſt my Contemplation?
Is it your tricke to make me ope the dore,
That ſo my ſad decrees may ﬂie away,
And all my ſtudie be to no effeƈt?
You are deceiu’d, for what I meane to do,
See heere in bloody lines I haue ſet downe:
And what is written ſhall be executed.

speech.speaker: Tam.
speech.line: Titus, I am come to talke with thee,

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: No not a word: how can I grace my talke,
Wanting a hand to giue it aƈtion,
Thou haſt the ods of me, therefore no more.

speech.speaker: Tam.
speech.line: If thou did’ſt know me,
Thou would’ſt talke with me.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: I am not mad, I know thee well enough,
Witneſſe this wretched ſtump,
Witneſſe theſe crimſon lines,
Witneſſe theſe Trenches made by griefe and care,
Witneſſe the tyring day, and heauie night,
Witneſſe all ſorrow, that I know thee well
For our proud Empreſſe, Mighty Tamora:
Is not thy comming for my other hand?

speech.speaker: Tamo.
speech.line: Know thou ſad man, I am not Tamora,
She is thy Enemie, and I thy Friend,
I am Reuenge ſent from th’infernall Kingdome,
To eaſe the gnawing Vulture of the mind,
By working wreakefull vengeance on my Fœs:
Come downe and welcome me to this worlds light,
Conferre with me of Murder and of Death,
Ther’s not a hollow Caue or lurking place,
No Vaſt obſcurity, or Miſty vale,
Where bloody Murther or deteſted Rape,
Can couch for feare, but I will ﬁnde them out,
And in their eares tell them my dreadfull name,
Reuenge, which makes the foule offenders quake.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Art thou Reuenge? and art thou ſent to me,
To be a torment to mine Enemies?

speech.speaker: Tam.
speech.line: I am, therefore come downe and welcome me.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Dœ me ſome ſeruice ere I come to thee:
Lœ by thy ſide where Rape and Murder ſtands,
Now giue ſome ſurance that thou art Reuenge,
Stab them, or teare them on thy Chariot wheeles,
And then Ile come and be thy Waggoner,
And whirle along with thee about the Globes.
Prouide thee two proper Palfries, as blacke as Iet,
To hale thy vengefull Waggon ſwiﬅ away,
And ﬁnde out Murder in their guilty cares.
And when thy Car is loaden with their heads,
I will diſmount, and by the Waggon wheele,
Trot like a Seruile footeman all day long,
Euen from Eptons riſing in the Eaſt,
Vntill his very downefall in the Sea.
And day by day Ile do this heauy taſke,
So thou deſtroy Rapine and Murder there.

speech.speaker: Tam.
speech.line: Theſe are my Miniſters, and come with me.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Are them thy Miniſters, what are they call’d?

speech.speaker: Tam.
speech.line: Rape and Murder, therefore called ſo,
Cauſe they take vengeance of ſuch kind of men.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Good Lord how like the Empreſſe Sons they are,
And you the Empreſſe: But we worldly men,
Haue miſerable mad miſtaking eyes:
Oh ſweet Reuenge, now do I come to thee,
And if one armes imbracement will content thee,
I will imbrace thee in it by and by.

speech.speaker: Tam.
speech.line: This cloſing with him, ﬁts his Lunacie,
What ere I forge to feede his braine-ſicke ﬁts,
Do you vphold, and maintaine in your ſpeeches,
For now he ﬁrmely takes me for Reuenge,
And being Credulous in this mad thought,
Ile make him ſend for Lucius his Sonne,
And whil’ſt I at a Banquet hold him ſure,
Ile ﬁnd ſome cunning praƈtiſe out of hand
To ſcatter and diſperſe the giddie Gothes,
Or at the leaſt make them his Enemies:
See heere he comes, and I muſt play my theame.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Long haue I bene forlorne, and all for thee,
Welcome dread Fury to my wœfull houſe,
Rapine and Murther, you are welcome too,
How like the Empreſſe and her Sonnes you are.
Well are you ﬁtted, had you but a Moore,
Could not all hell afford you ſuch a deuill?
For well I wote the Empreſſe neuer wags;
But in her company there is a Moore,
And would you repreſent our Queene aright
It were conuenient you had ſuch a deuill:
But welcome as you are, what ſhall we dœ?

speech.speaker: Tam.
speech.line: What would’ſt thou haue vs dœ Andronicus?

speech.speaker: Dem.
speech.line: Shew me a Murtherer, Ile deale with him.

speech.speaker: Chi.
speech.line: Shew me a Villaine that hath done a Rape,
And I am ſent to be reueng’d on him.

speech.speaker: Tam.
speech.line: Shew me a thouſand that haue done thee wrong,
And Ile be reuenged on them all.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Looke round about the wicked ſtreets of Rome,
And when thou ﬁnd’ſt a man that’s like thy ſelfe,
Good Murder ſtab him, hee’s a Murtherer.
Gœ thou with him, and when it is thy hap
To ﬁnde another that is like to thee,
Good Rapine ſtab him, he is a Rauiſher.
Go thou with them, and in the Emperours Court,
There is a Queene attended by a Moore,
Well maiſt thou know her by thy owne proportion,
For vp and downe ſhe doth reſemble thee.
I pray thee dœ on them ſome violent death,
They haue bene violent to me and mine.

speech.speaker: Tam.
speech.line: Well haſt thou leſſon’d vs, this ſhall we do.
But would it pleaſe thee good Andronicus,
To ſend for Lucius thy thrice Valiant Sonne,
Who leades towards Rome a Band of Warlike Gothes,
And bid him come and Banquet at thy houſe.
When he is heere, euen at thy Solemne Feaſt,
I will bring in the Empreſſe and her Sonnes,
The Emperour himſelfe, and all thy Fœs,
And at thy mercy ſhall they ſtoop, and kneele,
And on them ſhalt thou eaſe, thy angry heart:
What ſaies Andronicus to this deuiſe?

scene.stagedir: Enter Marcus.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Marcus my Brother, ’tis ſad Titus calls,
Go gentle Marcus to thy Nephew Lucius,
Thou ſhalt enquire him out among the Gothes,
Bid him repaire to me, and bring with him
Some of the chiefeſt Princes of the Gothes,
Bid him encampe his Souldiers where they are,
Tell him the Emperour, and the Empreſſe too,
Feaſts at my houſe, and he ſhall Feaſt with them,
This do thou for my loue, and ſo let him,
As he regards his aged Fathers life.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: This will I do, and ſoone returne againe.

speech.speaker: Tam.
speech.line: Now will I hence about thy buſineſſe,
And take my Miniſters along with me.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Nay, nay, let Rape and Murder ſtay with me,
Or els Ile call my Brother backe againe,
And cleaue to no reuenge but Lucius.

speech.speaker: Tam.
speech.line: What ſay you Boyes, will you bide with him,
Whiles I gœ tell my Lord the Emperour,
How I haue gouern’d our determined ieſt?
Yeeld to his Humour, ſmooth and ſpeake him faire,
And tarry with him till I turne againe.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: I know them all, though they ſuppoſe me mad,
And will ore-reach them in their owne deuiſes,
A payre of curſed hell-hounds and their Dam.

speech.speaker: Dem.
speech.line: Madam depart at pleaſure, leaue vs heere.

speech.speaker: Tam.
speech.line: Farewell Andronicus, reuenge now gœs
To lay a complot to betray thy Fœs.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: I know thou doo’ſt, and ſweet reuenge farewell.

speech.speaker: Chi.
speech.line: Tell vs old man, how ſhall we be imploy’d?

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Tut, I haue worke enough for you to dœ,
Publius come hither, Caius, and Valentine.

speech.speaker: Pub.
speech.line: What is your will?

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Know you theſe two?

speech.speaker: Pub.
speech.line: The Empreſſe Sonnes
I take them, Chiron, Demetrius.

speech.speaker: Titus.
speech.line: Fie Publius, fie, thou art too much deceau’d,
The one is Murder, Rape is the others name,
And therefore bind them gentle Publius,
Caius, and Valentine, lay hands on them,
Oﬅ haue you heard me wiſh for ſuch an houre,
And now I ﬁnd it, therefore binde them ſure,

speech.speaker: Chi.
speech.line: Villaines forbeare, we are the Empreſſe Sonnes.

speech.speaker: Pub.
speech.line: And therefore do we, what we are commanded.
Stop cloſe their mouthes, let them not ſpeake a word,
Is he ſure bound, looke that you binde them faſt.Exeunt.

scene.stagedir: Enter Titus Andronicus with a knife, and Lauinia with a Baſon

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Come, come Lauinia, looke, thy Fœs are bound,
Sirs ſtop their mouthes, let them not ſpeake to me,
But let them heare what fearefull words I vtter.
Oh Villaines, Chiron, and Demetrius,
Here ſtands the ſpring whom you haue ſtain’d with mud,
This goodly Sommer with your Winter mixt,
You kil’d her husband, and for that vil’d fault,
Two of her Brothers were condemn’d to death,
My hand cut off, and made a merry ieſt,
Both her ſweet Hands, her Tongue, and that more deere
Then Hands or tongue, her ſpotleſſe Chaſtity,
Inhumaine Traytors, you conſtrain’d and for’ſt.
What would you ſay, if I ſhould let you ſpeake?
Villaines for ſhame you could not beg for grace.
Harke Wretches, how I meane to martyr you,
This one Hand yet is leﬅ, to cut your throats,
Whil’ſt that Lauinia tweene her ſtumps doth hold:
The Baſon that receiues your guilty blood.
You know your Mother meanes to feaſt with me,
And calls herſelfe Reuenge, and thinkes me mad.
Harke Villaines, I will grin’d your bones to duſt,
And with your blood and it, Ile make a Paſte,
And of the Paſte a Coffen I will reare,
And make two Paſties of your ſhamefull Heads,
And bid that ſtrumpet your vnhallowed Dam,
Like to the earth ſwallow her increaſe.
This is the Feaſt, that I haue bid her to,
And this the Banquet ſhe ſhall ſurfet on,
For worſe then Philomel you vſd my Daughter,
And worſe then Progne, I will be reueng’d,
And now prepare your throats: Lauinia come.
Receiue the blood, and when that they are dead,
Let me gœ grin’d their Bones to powder ſmall,
And with this hatefull Liquor temper it,
And in that Paſte let their vil’d Heads be bakte,
Come, come, be euery one ofﬁcious,
To make this Banket, which I wiſh might proue,
More ſterne and bloody then the Centaures Feaſt.
So now bring them in, for Ile play the Cooke,
And ſee them ready, gainſt their Mother comes.Exeunt.

scene.stagedir: Enter Lucius, Marcus, and the Gothes.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Vnckle Marcus, ſince ’tis my Fathers minde
That I repair to Rome, I am content.

speech.speaker: Goth.
speech.line: And ours with thine befall, what Fortune will.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Good Vnckle take you in this barbarous Moore,
This Rauenous Tiger, this accurſed deuill,
Let him receiue no ſuſtenance, fetter him,
Till he be brought vnto the Emperours face,
For teſtimony of her foule proceedings.
And ſee the Ambuſh of our Friends be ſtrong,
If ere the Emperour meanes no good to vs.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: Some deuill whiſper curſes in my eare,
And prompt me that my tongue may vtter forth,
The Venemous Mallice of my ſwelling heart.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Away Inhumaine Dogge, Vnhallowed Slaue,
Sirs, helpe our Vnckle, to conuey him in,Flouriſh.
The Trumpets ſhew the Emperour is at hand.

scene.stagedir: Sound Trumpets. Enter Emperour and Empreſſe, with Tribunes and others

speech.speaker: Sat.
speech.line: What, hath the Firemament more Suns then one?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: What bootes it thee to call thy ſelfe a Sunne?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Romes Emperour & Nephewe breake the parle
Theſe quarrels muſt be quietly debated,
The Feaſt is ready which the carefull Titus,
Hath ordained to an Honourable end,
For Peace, for Loue, for League, and good to Rome:
Pleaſe you therfore draw nie and take your places.

speech.speaker: Satur
speech.line: Marcus we will.Hoboyes.

scene.stagedir: A Table brought in. Enter Titus like a Cooke, placing the meat on the Table, and Lauinia with a vale ouer her face

speech.speaker: Titus.
speech.line: Welcome my gracious Lord,
Welcome Dread Queene,
Welcome ye Warlike Gothes, welcome Lucius,
And welcome all: although the cheere be poore,
’Twill ﬁll your ſtomacks, pleaſe you eat of it.

speech.speaker: Sat.
speech.line: Why art thou thus attir’d Andronicus?

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Becauſe I would be ſure to haue all well,
To entertaine your Highneſſe, and your Empreſſe.

speech.speaker: Tam.
speech.line: We are beholding to you good Andronicus?

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: And if your Highneſſe knew my heart, you were:
My Lord the Emperour reſolue me this,
Was it well done of raſh Virginius,
To ſlay his daughter with his owne right hand.
Becauſe ſhe was enfor’ſt, ſtain’d, and deﬂowr’d?

speech.speaker: Satur.
speech.line: It was Andronicus.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Your reaſon, Mighty Lord?

speech.speaker: Sat.
speech.line: Becauſe the Girle, ſhould not ſuruiue her ſhame,
And by her preſence ſtill renew his ſorrowes.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: A reaſon mighty, ſtrong, and effeƈtuall,
A patterne, preſident, and liuely warrant,
For me (moſt wretched) to performe the like:
Die, die, Lauinia, and thy ſhame with thee,
And with thy ſhame, thy Fathers ſorrow die.

scene.stagedir: He kils her.

speech.speaker: Sat.
speech.line: What haſt done, vnnaturall and vnkinde?

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Kil’d her for whom my teares haue made me blind.
I am as wofull as Virginius was,
And haue a thouſand times more cauſe then he.

speech.speaker: Sat.
speech.line: What was ſhe rauiſht? tell who did the deed,

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Wilt pleaſe you eat,
Wilt pleaſe your Highneſſe feed?

speech.speaker: Tam.
speech.line: Why haſt thou ſlaine thine onely Daughter?

speech.speaker: Titus.
speech.line: Not I, ’twas Chiron and Demetrius,
They rauiſht her, and cut away her tongue,
And they, ’twas they, that did her all this wrong.

speech.speaker: Satu.
speech.line: Go fetch them hither to vs preſently.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Why there they are both, baked in that Pie,
Whereof their Mother dantily hath fed,
Eating the ﬂeſh that ſhe herſelfe hath bred.
’Tis true, ’tis true, witneſſe my kniues ſharpe point.

scene.stagedir: He ſtabs the Empreſſe.

speech.speaker: Satu.
speech.line: Die franticke wretch, for this accurſed deed.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Can the Sonnes eye, behold his Father bleed?
There’s meede for meede, death for a deadly deed.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: You ſad fac’d men, people and Sonnes of Rome,
By vprores ſeuer’d like a ﬂight of Fowle,
Scattred by windes and high tempeſtuous guſts:
Oh let me teach you how, to knit againe
This ſcattred Corne, into one mutuall ſheafe,
Theſe broken limbs againe into one body.

speech.speaker: Goth.
speech.line: Let Rome herſelfe be bane vnto herſelfe,
And ſhee whom mightie kingdomes curſie too,
Like a forlorne and deſperate caſtaway,
Dœ ſhamefull execution on her ſelfe.
But if my froſtie ſignes and chaps of age,
Graue witneſſes of true experience,
Cannot induce you to attend my words,
Speake Romes deere friend, as er’ſt our Aunceſtor,
When with his ſolemne tongue he did diſcourſe
To loue-ſicke Didœs ſad attending eare,
The ſtory of that balefull burning night,
When ſubtil Greekes ſurpriz’d King Priams Troy:
Tell vs what Sinon hath bewicht our eares,
Or who hath brought the fatall engine in,
That giues our Troy, our Rome the ciuill wound.
My heart is not compaƈt of ﬂint nor ſteele,
Nor can I vtter all our bitter griefe,
But ﬂoods of teares will drowne my Oratorie,
And breake my very vttrance, euen in the time
When it ſhould moue you to attend me moſt,
Lending your kind hand Commiſeration.
Heere is a Captaine, let him tell the tale,
Your hearts will throb and weepe to heare him ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: This Noble Auditory, be it knowne to you,
That curſed Chiron and Demetrius
Were they that murdred our Emperours Brother,
And they it were that rauiſhed our Siſter,
For their fell faults our Brothers were beheaded,
Our Fathers teares deſpiſ’d, and baſely couſen’d,
Of that true hand that fought Romes quarrell out,
And ſent her enemies vnto the graue.
Laſtly, my ſelfe vnkindly baniſhed,
The gates ſhut on me, and turn’d weeping out,
To beg reliefe among Romes Enemies,
Who drown’d their enmity in my true teares,
And op’d their armes to imbrace me as a Friend:
And I am turned forth, be it knowne to you,
That haue preſeru’d her welfare in my blood,
And from her boſome tooke the Enemies point,
Sheathing the ſteele in my aduentrous body.
Alas you know, I am no Vaunter I,
My ſcars can witneſſe, dumbe although they are,
That my report is iuſt and full of truth:
But ſoﬅ, me thinkes I do digreſſe too much,
Cyting my worthleſſe praiſe: Oh pardon me,
For when no Friends are by, men praiſe themſelues,

speech.speaker: Marc.
speech.line: Now is my turne to ſpeake: Behold this Child,
Of this was Tamora deliuered,
The iſſue of an Irreligious Moore,
Chiefe Architeƈt and plotter of theſe wœs,
The Villaine is aliue in Titus houſe,
And as he is, to witneſſe this is true.
Now iudge what courſe had Titus to reuenge
Theſe wrongs, vnſpeakeable paſt patience,
Or more then any liuing man could beare.
Now you haue heard the truth, what ſay you Romaines?
Haue we done ought amiſſe? ſhew vs wherein,
And from the place where you behold vs now,
The poore remainder of Andronici,
Will hand in hand all headlong caſt vs downe,
And on the ragged ſtones beat forth our braines,
And make a mutuall cloſure of our houſe:
Speake Romaines ſpeake, and if you ſay we ſhall,
Lœ hand in hand, Lucius and I will fall.

speech.speaker: Emilli.
speech.line: Come come, thou reuerent man of Rome,
And bring our Emperour gently in thy hand,
Lucius our Emperour: for well I know,
The common voyce do cry it ſhall be ſo.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Lucius, all haile Romes Royall Emperour,
Gœ, gœ into old Titus ſorrowfull houſe,
And hither hale that miſbelieuing Moore,
To be adiudg’d ſome direfull ſlaughtering death,
As puniſhment for his moſt wicked life.
Lucius all haile to Romes gracious Gouernour.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Thankes gentle Romanes, may I gouerne ſo,
To heale Romes harmes, and wipe away her wœ.
But gentle people, giue me ayme a-while,
For Nature puts me to a heauy taſke:
Stand all aloofe, but Vnckle draw you neere,
To ſhed obſequious teares vpon this Trunke:
Oh take this warme kiſſe on thy pale cold lips,
Theſe ſorrowfull drops vpon thy bloud-ſlaine face,
The laſt true Duties of thy Noble Sonne.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Teare for teare, and louing kiſſe for kiſſe,
Thy Brother Marcus tenders on thy Lips:
O were the ſumme of theſe that I ſhould pay
Countleſſe, and inﬁnit, yet would I pay them.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Come hither Boy, come, come, and learne of vs
To melt in ſhowres: thy Grandſire lou’d thee well:
Many a time he danc’d thee on his knee:
Sung thee aſleepe, his Louing Breſt, thy Pillow:
Many a matter hath he told to thee,
Meete, and agreeing with thine Infancie:
In that reſpeƈt then, like a louing Childe,
Shed yet ſome ſmall drops from thy tender Spring,
Becauſe kinde Nature doth require it ſo:
Friends, ſhould aſſociate Friends, in Greefe and Wo.
Bid him farwell, commit him to the Graue,
Do him that kindneſſe, and take leaue of him.

speech.speaker: Boy.
speech.line: O Grandſire, Grandſire: euen with all my heart
Would I were Dead, ſo you did Liue againe.
O Lord, I cannot ſpeake to him for weeping,
My teares will choake me, if I ope my mouth.

speech.speaker: Romans.
speech.line: You ſad Andronici, haue done with wœs,
Giue ſentence on this execrable Wretch,
That hath beene breeder of theſe dire euents.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Set him breſt deepe in earth, and famiſh him:
There let him ſtand, and raue, and cry for foode:
If any one releeues, or pitties him,
For the offence, he dyes. This is our doome:
Some ſtay, to ſee him faſt’ned in the earth.

speech.speaker: Aron.
speech.line: O why ſhould wrath be mute, & Fury dumbe?
I am no Baby I, that with baſe Prayers
I ſhould repent the Euils I haue done.
Ten thouſand worſe, then euer yet I did,
Would I performe if I might haue my will:
If one good Deed in all my life I did,
I do repent it from my very Soule.

speech.speaker: Lucius.
speech.line: Some louing Friends conuey the Emp. hence,
And giue him buriall in his Fathers graue.
My Father, and Lauinia, ſhall forthwith
Be cloſed in our Houſholds Monument:
As for that heynous Tyger Tamora,
No Funerall Rite, nor man in mournfull Weeds:
No mournfull Bell ſhall ring her Buriall:
But throw her foorth to Beaſts and Birds of prey:
Her life was Beaſt-like, and deuoid of pitty,
And being ſo, ſhall haue like want of pitty.
See Iuſtice done on Aaron that damn’d Moore,
From whom, our heauy happes had their beginning:
Then aﬅerwards, to Order well the State,
That like Euents, may ne’re it Ruinate.Exeunt omnes.
